title: adjust a test to catch a bug in the code of Stream.select()

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

milestone.description: Bug fix maintenance release for 1.4.0

body:
### What does this PR do?

Fixes a bug in `Stream.select(inventory=...)` that leads to only one SEED ID getting through, no matter what. Internally the variable `id` also used for filtering was overwritten during the filtering by inventory so that it was set to the last SEED ID checked in the inventory and that being the only SEED IDs let through later on. 

### Why was it initiated?  Any relevant Issues?

fixes #3274

title: move pytest import into skip network decorator

labels.name: CI
labels.description: issue generally related to continuous integration

labels.name: ready for review
labels.description: PRs that are ready to be reviewed to get marked ready to merge

labels.name: build_docs
labels.description: Docs will be automatically built and deployed in github actions on pushes to the PR

body:
### What does this PR do?

The doc build action currently fails (eg [here](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/actions/runs/4325286632/jobs/7551241516)) because `obspy.core.utils.decorator` imports pytest and pytest isn't listed as a dependency in the `INSTALL_REQUIRES` section of setup.py. 

Since there may be other issues with users trying to use the decorators module without having pytest installed, I think the best course of action is simply move the pytest import into the function that uses it.

title: Fix beach pdf output when Axes instance is provided to plot into

milestone.description: Bug fix maintenance release for 1.4.0

body:
### What does this PR do?

This commit is a bug fix, which corrects a bug in the obspy/imaging/…beachball functions.

Specifically, when calling the functions beach(...) in obspy/imaging/mopad_wrapper.py or obspy/imaging/beachball.py with the arguments axes not equals None, there is always an error if save the plotted beachballs into vector files (e.g., .pdf or .eps).

To locate the error/bug, I found that the functions beach(...) calls the function matplotlib.transforms.IdentityTransform() to create a Transform object. However the created object does not have the method translate(...) that is essential for saving plots into vector files.

To fix the bug, it is simple by using the function matplotlib.transforms.Affine2D(np.identity(3)) instead of matplotlib.transforms.IdentityTransform() to create the Transform object. The object created by the former has the method translate(...) and hence allows for saving into vector files, while the object created by the latter does not. Excep this difference, the objects created by the two functions have the same behaviours.

### Why was it initiated?  Any relevant Issues?

fixes #2887 and supersedes #3241

title: Fix `beach` pdf output when `Axes` instance is provided to plot into

milestone.description: Bug fix maintenance release for 1.4.0

body:
### What does this PR do?

This commit is a bug fix, which corrects a bug in the `obspy/imaging/…beachball` functions.

Specifically, when calling the functions `beach(...)` in `obspy/imaging/mopad_wrapper.py` or `obspy/imaging/beachball.py` with the arguments `axes` not equals `None`, there is always an error if save the plotted beachballs into vector files (e.g., .pdf or .eps).

To locate the error/bug, I found that the functions `beach(...)` calls the function `matplotlib.transforms.IdentityTransform()` to create a Transform object. However the created object does not have the method `translate(...)` that is essential for saving plots into vector files.

To fix the bug, it is simple by using the function `matplotlib.transforms.Affine2D(np.identity(3))` instead of `matplotlib.transforms.IdentityTransform()` to create the Transform object. The object created by the former has the method `translate(...)` and hence allows for saving into vector files, while the object created by the latter does not. Excep this difference, the objects created by the two functions have the same behaviours.


### Why was it initiated?  Any relevant Issues?

fixes #2887

title: seedlink basic_client always runs get_info

milestone.description: Bug fix maintenance release for 1.4.0

body:
### Avoid duplicates

- [X] I searched existing issues

### Bug Summary

in clients/seedlink/basic_client.py, Line 132

`if any('*' in x for x in (network, station, location, channel)) \`
 `               or ('?' in x for x in (network, station)):` 
            
always evaluates to true, so self.get_info will be called no matter what.

What's actually needed is:

`if any('*' in x for x in (network, station, location, channel)) \` 
`                 or any('?' in x for x in (network, station)):`

title: writing catalog to NLL obs doesn't handle 12 (etc) channels properly

milestone.description: Next feature release after 1.3.0 (might be relabeled to 2.0.0, depending on content and scale)

body:
### Avoid duplicates

- [X] I searched existing issues

### Bug Summary

Noticing that when one exports a catalog object to NLL's obs format, it converts any channel outside of `ZNEH` to a `?`. Not really an issue as NLL still handles it fine.

e.g. obspy/io/nlloc line 400 or so
```
    for pick in catalog[0].picks:
        wid = pick.waveform_id
        station = wid.station_code or "?"
        component = wid.channel_code and wid.channel_code[-1].upper() or "?"
        if component not in "ZNEH":
            component = "?"
        onset = ONSETS_REVERSE.get(pick.onset, "?")
        phase_type = pick.phase_hint or "?"
        polarity = POLARITIES_REVERSE.get(pick.polarity, "?")
```

However when reading NLL's output `.hpy` file back in, this (presumably horizontal) channel is now converted to `N` which then becomes a problem if the station's actual channels are `12`.

It seems like a trivial fix to change ` if component not in "ZNEH"` to at least  `ZNE123H` (or even `ZNE123HABCUVWTR`?) unless I am missing something. I know NLL will handle 123 but not completely sure about the more esoteric channels. 



### Code to Reproduce

_No response_

### Error Traceback

_No response_

### ObsPy Version?

1.3.1.post0+390.g3ad5eee621.obspy.master

### Operating System?

_No response_

### Python Version?

_No response_

### Installation Method?

developer installation / from source / git checkout

title: Raising FDSNTooManyRequestsException in error handling typo

milestone.description: Next feature release after 1.3.0 (might be relabeled to 2.0.0, depending on content and scale)

body:
Hello,
according to this code, present also in the current version (1.3.1):

https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/0d77efd744c8aa6fc8bb9ac2fe367cbc86b1656b/obspy/clients/fdsn/client.py#L1836-L1838

the first argument of the mentioned exception appears to be a tuple. This causes a TypeError when effectively too many requests are done and the FDSNTooManyRequestsException raises:

```
TypeError: sequence item 0: expected str instance, tuple found
```
It seems to be a small typo since the other exceptions have simple strings as first argument.

title: fdsn: fix eida routing get_waveforms_bulk()

labels.name: ready for review
labels.description: PRs that are ready to be reviewed to get marked ready to merge

labels.name: test_network
labels.description: tell github actions to also run network tests for this PR

milestone.description: Next feature release after 1.3.0 (might be relabeled to 2.0.0, depending on content and scale)

body:
### What does this PR do?

fix eida routing get_waveforms_bulk()

see test fail in https://tests.obspy.org/130191, warnings section has the relevant info showing the xml parser choking up on something that isn't xml.

Internally was making a call to `get_stations_bulk()` of the routing client with `format='text'` but that routing client routine internally uses a special format `post` specific to the routing web service. For some reason having `format='text'` in there made some server response get read as StationXML when it wasn't.. weird.

This also makes `get_stations_bulk()` of the routing client reject `format` kwarg, since this doesn't make sense anyway as internally it uses `post` format special to EIDA routing web service.

### Why was it initiated?  Any relevant Issues?

This problem surfaced as a side effect of #3212 so it's not in a released version and no changelog needed.

title: FDSNWS EIDA routing client broken when setting "debug=True"

milestone.description: Next feature release after 1.3.0 (might be relabeled to 2.0.0, depending on content and scale)

body:
### Avoid duplicates

- [X] I searched existing issues

### Bug Summary

Seems there is a problem in EIDAWS routing client. It seems it does not get any data back because `timeout` parameter is injected in the request and that is not expected. Looks like this was introduced by #3021 

EDIT: Actually this only affects the client with option `debug=True`. I ran into this looking into a different issue.

### Code to Reproduce

```python
from obspy.clients.fdsn import RoutingClient
client = RoutingClient("eida-routing", debug=True)
client.get_stations(station='B*', level='station', format='text')
```


### Error Traceback

```Python traceback
File ~/miniconda3/envs/master/lib/python3.10/site-packages/decorator.py:232, in decorate.<locals>.fun(*args, **kw)
    230 if not kwsyntax:
    231     args, kw = fix(args, kw, sig)
--> 232 return caller(func, *(extras + args), **kw)

File ~/git/obspy/obspy/clients/fdsn/routing/routing_client.py:78, in _assert_filename_not_in_kwargs(f, *args, **kwargs)
     76 if "filename" in kwargs:
     77     raise ValueError("The `filename` argument is not supported")
---> 78 return f(*args, **kwargs)

    125 @_assert_filename_not_in_kwargs
    126 def get_stations(self, **kwargs):
    127     """
    128     Get stations from multiple data centers.
    129 
   (...)
    147     for details.
    148     """
--> 149     return super(EIDAWSRoutingClient, self).get_stations(**kwargs)

File ~/miniconda3/envs/master/lib/python3.10/site-packages/decorator.py:232, in decorate.<locals>.fun(*args, **kw)
    230 if not kwsyntax:
    231     args, kw = fix(args, kw, sig)
--> 232 return caller(func, *(extras + args), **kw)

File ~/git/obspy/obspy/clients/fdsn/routing/routing_client.py:78, in _assert_filename_not_in_kwargs(f, *args, **kwargs)
     76 if "filename" in kwargs:
     77     raise ValueError("The `filename` argument is not supported")
---> 78 return f(*args, **kwargs)
```

title: polarity analysis: fix calculation of timestamp for sliding windows

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

labels.name: ready for review
labels.description: PRs that are ready to be reviewed to get marked ready to merge

milestone.description: Next feature release after 1.3.0 (might be relabeled to 2.0.0, depending on content and scale)

body:
### What does this PR do?

Fixes calculation of timestamps of sliding windows in polarization analysis for methods `pm` and `flinn`. Timestamp was supposed to be calculated as the center of the window, but was instead calculated as window start plus window shifting fraction, i.e. as the start time of the next window.
With window fraction `0.5` the timestamp calculation actually was yielding the expected result, but with lower or higher values yielded values shifted from the expected value by up to half the length of a single time window.

### Why was it initiated?  Any relevant Issues?

Fixes #2811

```
pip install git+https://github.com/trichter/obspycsv.git
```

### Code to Reproduce

```python
# first test fail
import io
from obspy import UTCDateTime, read_events
from obspy.core.event import Event, Origin
origin = Origin(time=UTCDateTime('2016-01-01'))
event1 = Event(origins=[origin])
bio = io.BytesIO()
event1.write(bio, 'quakeml')  # its working with a real file
```

### Bug Summary

Hi, I am having problems reading seg2 files if the keyword 'NOTE' exists but has no contents behind :

Initial code (function "parse_free_form" near the end, around line 327 in file seg2.py:

```
       if key == 'NOTE':
            value = [cleanup_and_decode_string(line)
                     for line in value.split(self.line_terminator)
```

```
        if key == 'NOTE':
```

title: set_flags_in_fixed_headers: wrong use of sampling rate

milestone.description: Bug fix maintenance release for 1.3.0 (if needed)

body:
### Avoid duplicates

- [X] I searched existing issues

### Bug Summary

My code generates mseed files and calls the function `obspy.io.mseed.util.set_flags_in_fixed_headers`.
The flags to be set are of the 'DURATION' kind and I could observe in the resulting files that some records had the flags set when they should not wrt to their data dates.

I looked into the  code of this function and I think I found a buggy line. In obspy-1.3, it is in
obspy/io/mseed/util.py:1160-1163
```
                # date of the last sample is recstart+samp_rate*(nb_samples-1)
                # We assume here that a record with samples [0, 1, ..., n]
                # has a period [ date_0, date_n+1 [  AND NOT [ date_0, date_n ]
                realendtime = recstart + samp_rate * (nb_samples)
```
As far I understand it, it should be :
```
                # date of the last sample is recstart+(nb_samples-1)/samp_rate
                # We assume here that a record with samples [0, 1, ..., n]
                # has a period [ date_0, date_n+1 [  AND NOT [ date_0, date_n ]
                realendtime = recstart + nb_samples / samp_rate
```

What comforts me in this analysis is the line 814 of the same file, in the function `_get_record_information`:
```
        info['endtime'] = starttime + (npts - 1) / samp_rate
```


### Code to Reproduce

_No response_

### Error Traceback

_No response_

### ObsPy Version?

1.0.2 and 1.3 (and probably all intermediates)

### Operating System?

CentOS

### Python Version?

2.7

### Installation Method?

pip

title: fdsn.client: add query parameters to get_station_bulk()

milestone.description: Next feature release after 1.3.0 (might be relabeled to 2.0.0, depending on content and scale)

body:
### Problem

The get_station_bulk() method implements the FDSNWS station POST query requests. However, while the standard supports various query parameters, get_station_bulk() currently supports only a subset as key=value pairs at the start of the request body:  level, includerestriced (typo!), includeavailability.

### Proposed solution

Add query parameters supported by the standard and/or the service endpoint. 

Some extra complexity is caused by the fact that most parameters are only "optional" and the specs are not very clear about the set of supported parameters. For GET method the set of supported parameters is declared by  `application.wadl`. It is used by ObsPy to discover available parameters for an endpoint. For POST this seems not to apply and it is not clear if we can assume that the same parameters are supported by GET and POST request.

* get_station_bulk() should support at least all "required" parameters, i.e. minlatitude, maxlatitude, minlongitude, maxlongitude;

* Optional parameters includerestricted and includeavailability are already available, though they might not be supported by the service endpoint because "optional";

* format and nodata (optional) seem particularly useful.

title: client.fdsn: query POST request Content-Type

milestone.description: Bug fix maintenance release for 1.3.0 (if needed)

body:
### Avoid duplicates

- [X] I searched existing issues

### Bug Summary

During the testing of a new FDSNWS station service application a problem surfaced when we started using ObsPy's  FDSN client with bulk requests. 

When using `client.get_station_bulk()` the request is send as a POST request, with method `query` and a POST payload which is specified in the FDSN standard [1]. The format of the payload is probably best described as text, though this is not explicitly mentioned in the document [2]. 

The ObsPy client sets the HTTP header `Content-Type` to the value `application/x-www-form-urlencoded`. We concluded that this Content-Type does **not** correctly describing the content of the provided body payload. For this `Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded` we expect to receive a content of the following pattern:
```
key1=value1&key2=value2
```
These are then interpreted in a similar way as query parameters in the URL string.

The problem with setting the wrong Content-Type is that various frameworks attempt to interpret the provided payload, do not provide any data as "body", fail due to an unexpected content wrt. to the header declaration and therefore behave in an unpredictable way.  

Note: 
There is a closely related issue #2364, were the same problem was already discussed in the contest of a similar problem. I however opt to open this new which focused  specifically on the Content-Type Header provided by ObsPy's FDSN client and the provided POST body payload. 

* [1] http://fdsn.org/webservices/fdsnws-station-1.1.pdf
* [2] https://github.com/FDSN/fdsnws-station/issues/8


### Code to Reproduce

```python
from obspy.clients.fdsn import Client

bulk = [['IV', 'ACER', '*', 'BHZ,HHZ', '2021-01-01T00:00:00', '2021-12-31T00:00:00'],
        ['MN', 'AQU', '*', 'BHZ,HHZ', '2021-01-01T00:00:00', '2021-12-31T00:00:00']]

client = Client("INGV")
inv = client.get_stations_bulk(bulk)

# sniff traffic to check Header content
```


### Error Traceback

```Python traceback
none
```


### ObsPy Version?

1.3.0

### Operating System?

any, verified on macOS, Linux

### Python Version?

3.10.7 (probably not relevant)

### Installation Method?

_No response_

title: IRIS federator routing client does not match https:// URLs — affects RASPISHAKE

milestone.description: Bug fix maintenance release for 1.3.0 (if needed)

body:
### Avoid duplicates

- [X] I searched existing issues

### Bug Summary

I noticed that the `RoutingClient('iris-federator')` was never returning stations / data from the RASPISHAKE data center. Digging in, I found this line in the **federator** `_split_routing_response()` method: https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/9659cf3e4499fe15fa71bd0bd3a9600aca7f180e/obspy/clients/fdsn/routing/federator_routing_client.py#L167

Compare to this line in the **eidaws** `_split_routing_response()` method:
https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/9659cf3e4499fe15fa71bd0bd3a9600aca7f180e/obspy/clients/fdsn/routing/eidaws_routing_client.py#L195

Note the difference is that the **federator** ignores `https://` URLs. Well, RASPISHAKE's URL is `https://`, see [here](http://service.iris.edu/irisws/fedcatalog/1/query?net=AM&sta=RAF63&format=request&includeoverlaps=false&nodata=404):

> ```
> DATASELECTSERVICE=https://fdsnws.raspberryshakedata.com/fdsnws/dataselect/1/
> STATIONSERVICE=https://fdsnws.raspberryshakedata.com/fdsnws/station/1/
> ```

### Possible fix?

I imagine this is a quick fix, changing `"http://"` to `"http"` on line 167 to match how the **eidaws** URLs are handled. If this is indeed the case, I'm happy to make a PR.

### Code to Reproduce

```python
from obspy.clients.fdsn import Client, RoutingClient

kwargs = dict(network='AM', station='RAF63')

Client('RASPISHAKE').get_stations(**kwargs)  # GOOD: Returns Inventory with "Sending institution: SeisComP (RaspberryShake)"
RoutingClient('iris-federator').get_stations(**kwargs)  # BAD: Raises FDSNNoDataException, see attached error traceback
```

title: When reading a stationxml response stage into a generic ResponseStage object, decimation info is dropped

labels.name: .core.inventory
labels.description: issues related to our Inventory functionality

milestone.description: Bug fix maintenance release for 1.3.0 (if needed)

body:
### Avoid duplicates

- [X] I searched existing issues

### Bug Summary

The IRIS validation rule 423 tests stationxml response_stages to check for any
stage that *has* decimation + gain info specified, but has stage type that is *not* one of:
{'PolesZerosResponseStage', 'CoefficientsTypeResponseStage', 'FIRResponseStage', 'ResponseListResponseStage'}

IRIS checks this test against the stationxml file F1_423.xml which is meant to fail this test.

However, using obspy read_inventory() to read file F1_423.xml breaks the test since
read_inventory() reads this stage into a generic ResponseStage, but it *drops* the
stage decimation info (e.g., stage.decimation_input_sample_rate is set to None even though it
is specified for this stage).

Is this behavior correct ?  The allowed stage types are all descended from ResponseStage so I
don't see any reason why ResponseStage wouldn't allow decimation info, but perhaps obspy
is intentionally disallowing generic ResponseStage with decimation info (?)

Thanks!
-Mike

### Code to Reproduce

```python
from obspy import read_inventory

# First copy/paste the stationxml in the Traceback below to ./F1_423_small.xml
inv = read_inventory('F1_423_small.xml')

resp = inv.networks[0].stations[0].channels[0].response

# Note that decimation info is lost for stages 1 and 2:
for stage in resp.response_stages:
    print(stage.stage_sequence_number, type(stage), stage.decimation_input_sample_rate,  stage.decimation_factor, stage.stage_gain)
```

title: memory leak in stream.resample()

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

body:
### Avoid duplicates

- [X] I searched existing issues

### Bug Summary

I have multiple streams, each containing 1 trace, 1 day long, of data sampled at 246.4 samples/sec. I am attempting to downsample to 100 samples/sec. When using stream.resample(), the system memory usage increases with each stream resampled until all memory is consumed and the process is killed. When using the identical code with stream.interpolate(), memory usage stays approximately steady. The code below illustrates this problem. The miniseed files are mostly 173 MB each, so if needed I will have to find a way to provide access to them.

### Code to Reproduce

```python
import obspy as ob
import psutil as u
from pathlib import Path

# target data rate
DataRate = 100.0

# source files
FileDir = "<source miniseed directory>"
Match = ".m"

# downsample each file to show memory leak		
# step through all files in the target direcory	
InPath = Path(FileDir)
for InFile in InPath.iterdir():
	
	if InFile.is_file() and Match in InFile.name:
		DayStream = ob.read(str(InFile))

		print("before resample", DayStream)
		# filter before changing data rate to avoid aliasing
		FreqCorner = DataRate / 2.0
		DayStream.filter('lowpass', freq=FreqCorner, corners=4, zerophase=True)
	
		# resample to the target data rate
		# results in continuing increase in used memory
		DayStream.resample(DataRate)	
		
		# OR: interpolate to target data rate
		# results in approximately steady used memory
		# but is slower
		# ~ DayStream.interpolate(sampling_rate=DataRate, method="lanczos", a=100)
		
		print("after resample", DayStream)
		print("Used memory is", u.virtual_memory()[3])
```


### Error Traceback

_No response_

1.3.0

### Operating System?

Linux Mint

### Python Version?

3.8.10

pip

title: NRL get_response() is not calculating overall instrument_sensitivity correctly

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

milestone.description: Bug fix maintenance release for 1.3.0 (if needed)

body:
### Avoid duplicates

- [X] I searched existing issues

### Bug Summary

When nrl calls get_response() to form the requested response, it calls response.recalculate_overall_sensitivity(), which in turn calls the evalresp library, but for some reason, it is not calculating the gain of the stage 1 poles_zeros correctly - it is not using A0 to calculate the gain at the normalization_frequency, and hence gives the wrong instrument_sensitivity.value.

The fix is to call response.recalculate_overall_sensivitity() a second time (why is this different ??)

The code below shows the problem:

1. When I call nrl.get_response(datalogger_keys, sensor_keys), it calls a function very similar to the function get_response_from_nrl() in the snippet below.  It joins the sensor + datalogger stages from the NRL and then calls response.recalculate_overall_sensitivity() to calculate/set response.instrument_sentivitity.value at the poles_zero normalization_frequency (5 Hz in this case).  However, that value is not correct - it does not take into account the A0 normalization of the stage 1 poles_zeros.  e.g., it is the value you would get if you assumed that the poles_zeros stage was normalized to 1.0 by the normalization_factor A0, and you just multiplied all of the response_stage.stage_gains together.  In the current example, expanding the poles_zeros at the normalization_frequency and scaling this by A0 gives:            |G(f=5.0Hz)| = 2.2068, thus the correct sensitivity should be: 6.29145492e+08 x 2.2068 = 1.38842473e+09 at 5.0 Hz

2. If I call nrl.get_response() and then call response.recalculate_overall_sensitivity() a second time (remember it is being called inside nrl.get_response()), it returns the correct value.

3a./3b. Here I am showing the effect of nrl.get_response() - it does call response.recalculate_overall_sensitivity() and this does change the sensitivity.value, but for some reason, again, it is not taking into account the A0 normalization of the poles_zeros stage.

3c. Again, a second call to response.recalculate_overall_sensitivity() fixes the problem.


Output of code:
** 1. straight from nrl.get_response():
Instrument Sensitivity:
	Value: 629145492.3989668
	Frequency: 5.0
	Input units: M/S
	Input units description: Velocity in Meters per Second
	Output units: COUNTS
	Output units description: Digital Counts

** 2. nrl.get_response() + resp.recalculate_overall_sensitivity():
Instrument Sensitivity:
	Value: 1388424726.398958
	Frequency: 5.0
	Input units: M/S
	Input units description: Velocity in Meters per Second
	Output units: COUNTS
	Output units description: Digital Counts

** 3a. get_response_from_nrl() initial resp:
Instrument Sensitivity:
	Value: 419430.375
	Frequency: 1.0
	Input units: M/S
	Input units description: Velocity in Meters per Second
	Output units: COUNTS
	Output units description: Digital Counts

** 3b. get_response_from_nrl() after first recalculate:
Instrument Sensitivity:
	Value: 629145492.3989668
	Frequency: 5.0
	Input units: M/S
	Input units description: Velocity in Meters per Second
	Output units: COUNTS
	Output units description: Digital Counts

** 3c. get_response_from_nrl() after additional recalculate:
Instrument Sensitivity:
	Value: 1388424726.398958
	Frequency: 5.0
	Input units: M/S
	Input units description: Velocity in Meters per Second
	Output units: COUNTS
	Output units description: Digital Counts

### Code to Reproduce

```python
from obspy.clients.nrl import NRL
def main():

    nrl = NRL()
    sensor_keys = ['GEObit', 'S20']
    datalogger_keys = ['GEObit','SRi32S Normal Gain', '40 Vpp', 'Linear Phase', '200']
    resp = nrl.get_response(datalogger_keys, sensor_keys)
    print("** 1. straight from nrl.get_response():\n%s" % resp.instrument_sensitivity)
    resp.recalculate_overall_sensitivity()
    print("** 2. nrl.get_response() + resp.recalculate_overall_sensitivity():\n%s" % resp.instrument_sensitivity)
    dl_resp = get_response_from_nrl(nrl, datalogger_keys, sensor_keys)

def get_response_from_nrl(nrl, datalogger_keys, sensor_keys):
    """ should be nearly identical to nrl.get_response() code """

    dl_resp = nrl.get_datalogger_response(datalogger_keys)
    sensor_resp = nrl.get_sensor_response(sensor_keys)

    dl_resp.response_stages.pop(0)
    sensor_stage0 = sensor_resp.response_stages[0]
    dl_resp.response_stages.insert(0, sensor_stage0)
    dl_resp.instrument_sensitivity.input_units = sensor_stage0.input_units
    dl_resp.instrument_sensitivity.input_units_description = sensor_stage0.input_units_description

    print("** 3a. get_response_from_nrl() initial resp:\n%s" % dl_resp.instrument_sensitivity)
    try:
        dl_resp.recalculate_overall_sensitivity()   ## This is not doing the trick!
    except ValueError:
        msg = "Failed to recalculate overall sensitivity"
        print(msg)
    print("** 3b. get_response_from_nrl() after first recalculate:\n%s" % dl_resp.instrument_sensitivity)

    dl_resp.recalculate_overall_sensitivity()
    print("** 3c. get_response_from_nrl() after additional recalculate:\n%s" % dl_resp.instrument_sensitivity)

    return dl_resp

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```


### Error Traceback

_No response_

### ObsPy Version?

1.3.0

### Operating System?

mac osx 12.4

### Python Version?

3.10.5

### Installation Method?

conda

title: Inventory map plot: Missing legend and artifacts from legend setup

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

milestone.description: Bug fix maintenance release for 1.3.0 (if needed)

body:
### Avoid duplicates

- [X] I searched existing issues

### Bug Summary

With 9659cf3e4499fe15fa71bd0bd3a9600aca7f180e, while fixing the docs build apparently, two small bugs were introduced.

 a) Legend is removed from the plot, right after adding it
 b) Helper artists (bogus scatter plots), used to set up the legend are not removed anymore, ending up in markers lingering at 0°N 0°E

```diff
@@ -1010,20 +1013,20 @@ class Inventory(ComparingObject):
 
         if legend is not None and color_per_network:
             ax = fig.axes[0]
-            count = len(ax.collections)
             for code, color in sorted(color_per_network.items()):
                 ax.scatter([0], [0], size, color, label=code, marker=marker)
             # workaround for older matplotlib versions
             try:
-                ax.legend(loc=legend, fancybox=True, scatterpoints=1,
-                          fontsize="medium", markerscale=0.8,
-                          handletextpad=0.1)
+                leg = ax.legend(loc=legend, fancybox=True, scatterpoints=1,
+                                fontsize="medium", markerscale=0.8,
+                                handletextpad=0.1)
+                leg.remove()
             except TypeError:
                 leg_ = ax.legend(loc=legend, fancybox=True, scatterpoints=1,
                                  markerscale=0.8, handletextpad=0.1)
-                leg_.prop.set_size("medium")
+                leg_.remove()
             # remove collections again solely created for legend handles
-            ax.collections = ax.collections[:count]
+            # ax.collections = ax.collections[:count]
 
         if outfile:
             fig.savefig(outfile)
```
 a) is trivial, just get rid of these remove calls again
 b) currently calls like `.pop()` and `.remove()` work on `ax.collections`, but there's a [note that with matplotlib 3.7 this will get changed to being immutable](https://github.com/matplotlib/matplotlib/blob/c6c7ec1978c22ae2c704555a873d0ec6e1e2eaa8/lib/matplotlib/axes/_base.py#L1327-L1336), so this needs to be done differently and correctly right now


---

In addition, this part also shows a warning:

```
*c* argument looks like a single numeric RGB or RGBA sequence, which should be avoided as value-mapping will have precedence in case its length matches with *x* & *y*.  Please use the *color* keyword-argument or provide a 2D array with a single row if you intend to specify the same RGB or RGBA value for all points.
```

This simply needs to be changed to `color=color`:

```
ax.scatter([0], [0], size, color, label=code, marker=marker)
```

### Code to Reproduce

```python
from obspy import read_inventory

inv = read_inventory()
inv.plot(color_per_network=True, projection='global')
```


### Error Traceback

_No response_

### ObsPy Version?

master

### Operating System?

_No response_

### Python Version?

_No response_

title: Station.identifiers[0] should not be URI type

labels.name: .core.inventory
labels.description: issues related to our Inventory functionality

milestone.description: Next major release, dropping Python 2 support and being the first Python 3 only release.

body:
Hello!
Just want to say that obspy continues to be an incredibly useful package!

I'm trying to set the identifiers on an obspy Station instance.
According to FDSN schema 1.1 IdentifierType should be a simple string with "type" attribute:
```
  <xs:complexType name="IdentifierType">
    <xs:annotation>
      <xs:documentation>A type to document persistent identifiers.
        Identifier values should be specified without a URI scheme (prefix),
        instead the identifer type is documented as an attribute.
      </xs:documentation>
    </xs:annotation>
    <xs:simpleContent>
      <xs:extension base="xs:string">
        <xs:attribute name="type" type="xs:string"> </xs:attribute>
      </xs:extension>
    </xs:simpleContent>
  </xs:complexType>

```
However, obspy (v.1.2.2) seems to have encoded this as xsd:anyURI type instead:

>>> wes.identifiers = ['10.157778/RESIF.FR']
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/mth/mth/miniconda3/envs/test_yasmine/lib/python3.8/site-packages/obspy/core/inventory/util.py", line 123, in identifiers
    _warn_on_invalid_uri(identifier)
  File "/Users/mth/mth/miniconda3/envs/test_yasmine/lib/python3.8/site-packages/obspy/core/inventory/util.py", line 1076, in _warn_on_invalid_uri
    msg = "Given string seems to not be a valid URI: ''" % uri
TypeError: not all arguments converted during string formatting

```
>>> wes.identifiers=['http://10.16778/RESIF.FR', 'http://32.2323/RESIF.CR']
>>> print("obspy is happy now!")
```

Tracking it down a bit further:

core/inventory/util.py:
```
    @identifiers.setter
    def identifiers(self, value):
        if not hasattr(value, "__iter__"):
            msg = "identifiers needs to be an iterable, e.g. a list."
            raise ValueError(msg)
        # make sure to unwind actual iterators, or the just might get exhausted
        # at some point
        identifiers = [identifier for identifier in value]
        for identifier in identifiers:
            _warn_on_invalid_uri(identifier)
        self._identifiers = identifiers
```

This calls:

```
def _warn_on_invalid_uri(uri):
    if not _is_valid_uri(uri):
        msg = "Given string seems to not be a valid URI: ''" % uri
        warnings.warn(msg)
```

And that msg seems to be missing the %s format to print uri and that seems to be
the error I'm getting.

So I guess there are 2 things:
1. identifiers - sholudn't be checked as valid_uri, at least not for basenode types
2. the _warn_on_invalid_uri() func has an error in msg.


Thanks!
-Mike

title: Bugs when saving plotted beachballs to .pdf or .eps figures

milestone.description: Bug fix maintenance release for 1.4.0

body:
https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/477659fe6fc940b87a2ffee09a47e6b34438bdf4/obspy/imaging/beachball.py#L167

I encountered a bug in plotting beachballs for source mechanisms. Specifically, when calling the functions `beach(...)` in `obspy/imaging/mopad_wrapper.py` or `obspy/imaging/beachball.py` with the arguments `axes` not equals `None`, there is always an error if save the plotted beachballs into vector files (e.g., .pdf or .eps).

To locate the error/bug, I found that the functions `beach(...)` calls the function
`matplotlib.transforms.IdentityTransform()` to create a Transform object. However, the
created object does not have the method `translate(...)` that is essential for saving
plots into vector files.

To fix the bug, it is simple by using the function `matplotlib.transforms.Affine2D(np.identity(3))`
instead of `matplotlib.transforms.IdentityTransform()` to create the Transform object.
The object created by the former has the method `translate(...)` and hence allows for
saving into vector files, while the object created by the latter does not.
Except for this difference, the objects created by the two functions have the same behaviors.

I have fixed the bug in my fork. The commit is my fork is here.
https://github.com/sheng09/obspy/commit/ac85a77e317f76ff4fd68505a18656c5d41a6e34
The fixing is very simple so that I revise in the master branch. Therefore, I simply raise the issue here instead of
newing a pull request. But I can new a PR if you think it is ok.

Below is an example for saving beachball plots into .pdf file. Without the fix, errors always happen. With the fix, errors disappear.

```python3
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import obspy.imaging.beachball as beachball

fig = plt.figure(figsize=(18, 5.5) )
ax = fig.add_subplot(111, aspect='equal')

bb = beachball.beach((0, 45, 90), facecolor='k', width=30, axes=ax, xy=(0, 0) )
ax.add_collection(bb)

plt.savefig('test.pdf')
```

title: NORDIC write of pick with 0. seconds leaves second field empty

when writing out to a NORDIC file, obspy will output blanks when the seconds=0.  This is not standard NORDIC format and will not be read by obspy itself.

Here is a code that illustrates the point, using the attached file:

```python
from obspy.core.event import read_events
cat = read_events('nordic.txt', format='NORDIC')
cat.write('nordic2.txt', format='NORDIC')
cat = read_events('nordic2.txt', format='NORDIC')
```

title: taup arrival times are wrong for custom velocity model
body:
<!--

**GitHub should mainly be used for bug reports and code developments/discussions. For generic questions, please use either the [[obspy-users] mailing list](http://lists.swapbytes.de/mailman/listinfo/obspy-users) (for scientific questions to the general ObsPy community) or our [gitter chat](https://gitter.im/obspy/obspy) (for technical questions and direct contact to the developers).**

Before submitting an Issue, please review the [Issue Guidelines](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-an-issue).

-->

(I've seen numerous closed/open issues that report bugs with taup, but I did not immediately recognise my problem as being a duplicate of previously opened issues. Please forgive my possible duplicate report)

# Problem description

I've been playing around with taup models for solving hydro-acoustic problems. To this end I created a custom velocity model (`tvel` format) using IASPEI91 as a starting model. For some reason I get various error messages when removing redundant layers, but that's a problem for another day.

`acoustic_model.tvel`:

```
Modified IASPEI91 model
Anything below 2.75 km is bogus
     0.000    1.5062    0.001     1.0
     2.750    1.5493    0.001     1.0
     2.750    5.8000    3.3600    2.7200
    20.000    5.8000    3.3600    2.7200
    20.000    6.5000    3.7500    2.9200
    35.000    6.5000    3.7500    2.9200
    35.000    8.0400    4.4700    3.3198
```

When I run the following code, I get some results, but the arrival times (even the direct ones) are completely wrong:

```
import os
import obspy
from obspy.taup import TauPyModel
from obspy.taup.velocity_model import VelocityModel
from obspy.taup.taup_create import build_taup_model

filename = "acoustic_model.tvel"

vmodel = VelocityModel.read_tvel_file(filename)
assert vmodel.validate()

taup_model = build_taup_model(filename, output_folder=os.getcwd())

model = TauPyModel(model=f"{filename[:-5]}.npz")

arrivals = model.get_ray_paths(
    source_depth_in_km=2.,
    distance_in_degree=5,
)

print(arrivals[:2])

fig = plt.figure(figsize=(9, 5), constrained_layout=True)
ax = arrivals[:2].plot_rays(plot_type="cartesian", fig=fig)
```

Output:
```
2 arrivals
	p phase arrival at 2.349 seconds
	P phase arrival at 2.696 seconds
```

![taup](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6959003/112023689-c3d45e80-8b33-11eb-9241-8e26f50fce22.png)

While I find it curious that the diffracted arrival does not exactly hit the receiver, I am more worried about the direct phase which supposedly arrives after 2.3 seconds. The acoustic speed in water is about 1.5 km/s, so to bridge a 5 degree gap would take about 6 minutes (which I verified with an Eikonal simulation).

# Other information

ObsPy version: `1.2.2`
Installation method: `conda`
Operating system: `Linux Mint 19`

title: signal->polarization: incorrect timestamp of window

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

milestone.description: Next feature release after 1.3.0 (might be relabeled to 2.0.0, depending on content and scale)

body:
The timestamp assigned to the time windows in polarization analysis is imho incorrect.

polarization.py presently:
```
540             # we plot against the centre of the sliding window
541             if method.lower() == "pm":
542                 azimuth, incidence, error_az, error_inc = \
543                     particle_motion_odr(data, var_noise)
544                 res.append(np.array([newstart.timestamp + float(nstep) / fs,
545                            azimuth, incidence, error_az, error_inc]))
546             if method.lower() == "flinn":
547                 azimuth, incidence, reclin, plan = flinn(data, var_noise)
548                 res.append(np.array([newstart.timestamp + float(nstep) / fs,
549                                     azimuth, incidence, reclin, plan]))
```

plotting against the centre of the sliding window (comment in line 540) makes full sense 
but then lines 544 and 548 should be:
```
                     res.append(np.array([newstart.timestamp + float(nsamp) / 2 / fs,
```

### Why?
- `nsamp` is no of samples of sliding window
- `nstep` is no of samples to shift window from one timestamp to the next

if `win_frac = 0.5` (fraction of sliding window), the original version is correct.
else the timestamp will not be the center of the current timewindow but the starttime of the next timewindow.

### Example 
with `win_len = 0.3` and `win_frac = 0.1`
- original: polarization signal is shifted to earlier times than signal peak in waveform (P-pol pick is not central)
![polarization original](https://github.com/cweidle/tmpimages/raw/main/syndata_BAZ_045_INC_90_pol_BUG.png)

- fixed: polarization signal is centered around P-pol pick
![polarization fixed](https://github.com/cweidle/tmpimages/raw/main/syndata_BAZ_045_INC_90_pol.png)

body:
**Background Info**

- ObsPy version 1.2.2, installed in a conda environment from the conda-forge channel
- Python 3.8.5
- Windows 10

**Steps to Reproduce**

- Create a SEED file with the station elevation set to exactly 0 (I have an example file but I can't figure out how to attach it, Github doesn't like the extension)
- Run the following code:
```
from obspy import read_inventory
inv = read_inventory("XX.TEST.seed", format="SEED")
station = inv[0][0]
print(station)
```
Results:
```
Station TEST (Test)
        Station Code: TEST
        Channel Count: None/None (Selected/Total)
        2020-12-01T00:00:00.000000Z -
        Access: None
        Latitude: 45.34, Longitude: -75.90, Elevation: 123456.0 m
        Available Channels:
                TEST..HHZ, TEST..HHN, TEST..HHE
```
Notice the elevation is set to 123456.0 m, whereas in the original file (you'll have to trust me on this) it was 0.0

I believe this is caused by this line in `_parse_to_inventory_object` in [obspy.io.xseed.core](https://docs.obspy.org/_modules/obspy/io/xseed/core.html#_parse_to_inventory_object): `elevation=elevation or 123456.0` since exactly 0 maps to false.

For now we are working around this issue by adjusting our elevations to something just off zero (e.g. 0.1).

title: TSIndex bugs
body:
I'm trying to implement usage of TSIndex in my app and I found some bugs in the `Indexer` class of TSIndex

1. `leap_seconds_file="SEARCH"` and passing as `database`  an instance of `TSIndexDatabaseHandler` initialized not with argument `database` but with `session` raises error in method `_get_leap_seconds_file` on line `dbpath = os.path.dirname(self.request_handler.database)`. The request handler in this case does not have a `database` attribute. Changing value of `leap_seconds_file` fixes the problem because the if/else skips that part.
2. `Indexer.run` will likely not run either due to the same reason. If address will not be explicitly provided, to `Indexer` in `bulk_params["-sqlite"]`, and database will be passed as described before, this code will raise an exception:
```
        if self.bulk_params.get("-sqlite") is None:
            # set path to sqlite database
            self.bulk_params['-sqlite'] = self.request_handler.database
```
3. TSIndex is not compatible with PostgreSQL despite of mseedindex being able to use it but I guess its a design decision

@chad-iris @nick-falco

Before submitting an Issue, please review the [Issue Guidelines](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-an-issue).

-->

* Please check whether the bug was already reported or fixed.
No
* Please provide the following information:
  -  ObsPy version, Python version and Platform (Windows, OSX, Linux ...)
obspy 1.2.2, Python 3.8.5, Linux
  -  How did you install ObsPy and Python (pip, anaconda, from source ...)
anaconda
* issue
https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/d56e8ebebc0b4d7797db8e5b2bb76e8e91df13de/obspy/io/sac/sacpz.py#L101

I am planning to write to a SACPZ file while `cha.sensor==None` which means it has no sensor information, the program will crash since `None.type` doesn't exit. The general purpose for us to use a SACPZ file is to remove the instrumental response and the sensor information might not be so essential. So maybe we can add an if flag here to see whether `cha.sensor` exist or not?

```
  File "/Users/adrien/.pyenv/versions/3.8.2/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/obspy/io/seiscomp/inventory.py", line 181, in _read_sc3ml
    networks.append(_read_network(instrumentation_register,
  File "/Users/adrien/.pyenv/versions/3.8.2/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/obspy/io/seiscomp/inventory.py", line 236, in _read_network

    channel.response = _read_response(instrumentation_register['responses'],
  File "/Users/adrien/.pyenv/versions/3.8.2/Python.framework/Versions/3.8/lib/python3.8/site-packages/obspy/io/seiscomp/inventory.py", line 663, in _read_response
```

I tracked this down and it is due to the fact that if for a PAZ response of a channel (analogue stage of datalogger), the number of zeros is zero (`<numberOfZeros>0</numberOfZeros>`), the `<zeros>` field is not written to the xml file (same thing for the poles) instead of being written but empty. 

I use ObsPy version 1.2.1 installed using pip on macOS 10.15, with python3 installed in pyenv environment.

nor seconds outside the range of 0..59.  Neither of these are explicitly allowed (or disallowed)

```python
inv = read_inventory('OO_SP_stationonly.xml')
cat = read_events('ph2dt_example_errors.dat', 'HYPODDPHA', inventory=inv,
                  id_default='OO.{}.00.EH{}')
print(cat)
```

Before submitting an Issue, please review the [Issue Guidelines](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-an-issue).

Reported on the users mailing list:

---

I'm using the NRL routines based on the below website:

https://docs.obspy.org/tutorial/code_snippets/stationxml_file_from_scratch.html

However, there is an error either on the Obspy end or the IRIS end, because when I try to pull a 36db gain RESPONSE file, I get the 0db RESPONSE file:

Python Code:

```python
print(nrl.dataloggers["DTCC (manufacturers of SmartSolo"]["SmartSolo IGU-16"]["0 dB (1)"]["500"]["Minimum Phase"]["Off"])
print(nrl.dataloggers["DTCC (manufacturers of SmartSolo"]["SmartSolo IGU-16"]["36 dB (64)"]["500"]["Minimum Phase"]["Off"])
```

Results (the same RESPONSE file):

```
('SmartSolo IGU-16, 0 dB gain, 500 sps, minimum phase final filters, low cut off', 'http://ds.iris.edu/NRL/dataloggers/dtcc/igu16/RESP.XX.DT046..DPZ.SSOLO_IGU16.1.500.MP.OFF')
('SmartSolo IGU-16, 0 dB gain, 500 sps, minimum phase final filters, low cut off', 'http://ds.iris.edu/NRL/dataloggers/dtcc/igu16/RESP.XX.DT046..DPZ.SSOLO_IGU16.1.500.MP.OFF')﻿
```

---

This looks like an actual bug and actually pretty severe so this should be fixed on 1.2.x maintenance branch.

title: Trace.copy: Using deepcopy causes derived Stats keys setting parent keys with computed values (leading to wrong values in edge cases)

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

body:
Hi everybody,

First, I hope all of you are happy and healthy.

Second, I've got a puzzling issue when working with highly-sampled data:

-  ObsPy version: 1.2.1 (anaconda)
-  Python version: 3.7
-  Arch Linux

Working with sampling rates >= 100000. Hz produces unexpected behavior.

```
tr = Trace(data=np.ones(100000), header={'sampling_rate': 100000.})
print(tr.stats.sampling_rate)
100000.0
print(tr.copy().stats.sampling_rate)
99999.99999999999
```
I think this is a result of floating point ["representation error"](https://docs.python.org/3/tutorial/floatingpoint.html), whenever the Trace AttribDict needs to be re-evaluated, [specifically where `delta` is involved](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/88687a146a7c3ca8f35c608db2243cf5fed6813c/obspy/core/trace.py#L177-L182).

Not sure how to go about addressing this though...

Now gives a warning and jumps out.

There are a few minor additions (but no new features) in the ellipse.py code that I had written in the meantime but not submitted.  When one of my students reported the crash I tested my updated code, which worked.  So I am submitting the full updated code.  I also added a unittest

body:
<!--

Thank your for contributing to ObsPy!

!! Please check that you select the **correct base branch** (details see below link) !!

Before submitting a PR, please review the pull request guidelines:
https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#submitting-a-pull-request

Also, please make sure you are following the ObsPy branching model:
https://github.com/obspy/obspy/wiki/ObsPy-Git-Branching-Model

-->

### What does this PR do?

Fixes a minor bug in plotting inventories' response. When providing existing `axes` for amplitude/phase response as arrays (e.g. grabbing axes from after `fig, axes = plt.subplots(ncols=2, nrows=2)`), an exception is raised by numpy because `bool()` is not defined on arrays.

```
  File ".../lib/python3.7/site-packages/obspy/core/inventory/response.py", line 1795, in plot
    if axes:
ValueError: The truth value of an array with more than one element is ambiguous. Use a.any() or a.all()
```

It's easy to avoid for users by using `my_axes.tolist()` if its an array, but it should still be fixed in next release.

title: polarization.vidale_adapt: possible mis-ordered complex covariance matrix elements

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

milestone.description: TRFKAP  --  The release formerly known as "pre-EGU 2018 release"

body:
Obspy version:1.1.0, python version: 3.7

Two elements of the complex covariance matrix in obspy.signal.polarization.vidale_adapt are possibly mis-ordered.

Lines 270 and 271 of obspy.signal.polarization.py are currently
```
covmat[1][2] = np.dot(zx, nx.conjugate())
covmat[2][1] = covmat[1][2].conjugate()
```

Suggest it should be:
```
covmat[1][2] = np.dot(nx, zx.conjugate())
covmat[2][1] = covmat[1][2].conjugate()
```

Tests suggest that current implementation produces significantly noisier smallest eigenvalues than suggested fix.

[Apologies if I've not formatted this issue correctly, or mis-understood the code; first attempt at raising an issue - please let me know if I should be doing something else].

title: Infinite loop when trying to read full SEED file without any mini SEED records

milestone.description: TRFKAP  --  The release formerly known as "pre-EGU 2018 release"

body:
When trying to read a full SEED file without any mini SEED records, while specifying input format MSEED, the code runs into an infinite loop.

Example file (contained FSEED file): http://webservices.ingv.it/webservices/ingv_ws_data/data/view_waveform_at_ingv.it/2015/08/24/093006_1594696/1594696_data.tgz

Code to reproduce:
```
import obspy
obspy.read('1594696_data/1594696_data.fseed', 'MSEED')
```

Code gets stuck searching for first data record, in the following loop:
https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/6d6d20c7c35126b18de5d33af962aa1c51dbfdd7/obspy/io/mseed/util.py#L646

I suppose the problem could be fixed with a check if EOF has been reached. For intended behavior I'm unsure if an exception should be raise or rather if just an empty Stream object should be returned.

title: read_inventory converts empty sub-elements to the 'None' string

labels.name: .core.inventory
labels.description: issues related to our Inventory functionality

milestone.description: TRFKAP  --  The release formerly known as "pre-EGU 2018 release"

body:
When read_inventory() reads a stationxml file, it converts empty sub-elements to the 'None' string.

Looking at obspy/io/stationxml/core.py:

```python
710 def _read_equipment(equip_element, _ns):
713     description = _tag2obj(equip_element, _ns("Description"), str)
...
1448 def _tag2obj(element, tag, convert):
1449     # we use future.builtins.str and are sure we have unicode here
1450     try:
1451         return convert(element.find(tag).text)
```

When an element is present (e.g., sensor) but the subelement is not (e.g., sensor.description),
_tag2obj returns str(None) which is the string 'None'.

So if a stationxml containing:

    <Sensor>
         <Description></Description>
    </Sensor>

is read in and then written back out using inventory.write(), it writes:

    <Sensor>
        <Description>None</Description>
    </Sensor>

i.e., it writes 'None' in place of the empty sub-element.
Is this intentional ?  I know the xsd specifies that a sensor must have a description, but I've seen stationxml files out in the wild that are missing it.

I just don't know if it's better to keep the field empty on disk (=None in memory) or to use the "None" string as placeholder ?

Thanks!

title: Fix gcf reading at Py38

body:
As #2469 shown, in Py38 gcf reading was failing. It turned out that `char()` do not allow anymore to pass as an argument a list which is the case here. So I changed it to pass only first and only element of the list.

I tested on 3.8 and 3.6 on my machine, let's see what Travis will say.

Based on branch ci_py38, rebased on current master.

Closes #2469

title: Cannot write zero sample rate trace data as miniSEED

milestone.description: TRFKAP  --  The release formerly known as "pre-EGU 2018 release"

body:
**Description of bug**
ObsPy cannot write zero sample rate miniSEED. This is important for non time series data, such as LOG channels.

**To reproduce the bug**
1.) Download some zero sample rate LOG data from the DMC.

e.g. http://service.iris.edu/fdsnws/dataselect/1/query?network=YW&channel=LOG&starttime=2016-01-01&endtime=2016-12-31&nodata=404

2.) Read this 0 sample rate data using ObsPy

```python
import obspy
st = obspy.read("fdsnws-dataselect_2019-10-23t18_11_00z.mseed")
```

3.) Try to write this data as miniSEED

```python
st.write('fdsnws-dataselect_2019-10-23t18_11_00z.mseed', format='MSEED')
```

resulting in the following exception

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
```

title: Plotting of small island coastlines with inventory.plot() and catalog.plot()

milestone.description: TRFKAP  --  The release formerly known as "pre-EGU 2018 release"

body:
ObsPy version 1.1.1; Python version: 3.7; Platform: OSX; installed using anaconda

I am making maps of earthquake epicentres and station locations for the Eastern Caribbean region using catalog.plot() and inventory.plot() respectively. Even though I have tried setting the map resolution to "h" and "f", many of the Lesser Antilles islands are not being plotted (only 2 out of the 10+ islands in the region are shown):
```
from obspy import read_inventory
inv = read_inventory("XX.xml")
inv.plot(projection="local", resolution="f", method="basemap", show=True)
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25796081/66199197-08e1a800-e696-11e9-929b-ac29d22f3f44.png)

I thought that this was an issue with the Basemap package, but when I run the following code, the map plots as it should and all islands show up:
```
from mpl_toolkits.basemap import Basemap
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
fig = plt.figure(figsize=(10,10))
map = Basemap(llcrnrlon=-65,llcrnrlat=10,urcrnrlon=-55.,urcrnrlat=20.,
             resolution='h', projection='tmerc', lat_0 = 16, lon_0 = -60)
map.drawmapboundary(fill_color='aqua')
map.fillcontinents(color='coral',lake_color='aqua')
map.drawcoastlines()
plt.show()
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25796081/66199427-7b528800-e696-11e9-8d5b-4d81840a5c84.png)

So it seems like this is an issue with how ObsPy is calling Basemap.

I have attached the corresponding STATIONXML file (zipped up) for reproducing this issue:
[XX.xml.zip](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/files/3690016/XX.xml.zip)

title: QuakeML reading: Elements of "http://quakeml.org" native namespace in custom tags section ignored

milestone.description: TRFKAP  --  The release formerly known as "pre-EGU 2018 release"

body:
When reading QuakeML files that contain custom elements which have a native `http://quakeml.org` namespace, these do not get properly deserialized into `.extra` dictionaries. Writing works, but reading back leaves them out.

```python
from obspy import Catalog, read_events

extra = {'my_tag_1': {'value': u'11111',
                      'namespace': 'http://quakeml.org/xmlns/quakeml/1.2'},
         'my_tag_2': {'value': u'22222',
                      'namespace': 'http://xxx.org/xmlns/quakeml/1.2'}}

cat = Catalog()
cat.extra = extra
cat.write('my_catalog.xml', format='QUAKEML')

cat2 = read_events('my_catalog.xml', format='QUAKEML')
print(cat2.extra)
```

xml output

```xml
<?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
<q:quakeml xmlns:ns0="http://xxx.org/xmlns/quakeml/1.2" xmlns:q="http://quakeml.org/xmlns/quakeml/1.2" xmlns="http://quakeml.org/xmlns/bed/1.2">
  <eventParameters publicID="smi:local/08724e77-3221-4989-ad8e-c6f0fc49d8bf">
    <ns0:my_tag_2>22222</ns0:my_tag_2>
    <q:my_tag_1>11111</q:my_tag_1>
  </eventParameters>
</q:quakeml>                                                                                                                                                                    
```

print output after running the read at end

```
AttribDict({'my_tag_2': AttribDict({'value': '22222', 'namespace': 'http://xxx.org/xmlns/quakeml/1.2'})})
```

title: Trace remove_response() method raises exception when used with numpy 1.17.0

milestone.description: TRFKAP  --  The release formerly known as "pre-EGU 2018 release"

body:
numpy version 1.17 has replaced the internal fftpack module with pocketfft (see release notes here: https://github.com/numpy/numpy/blob/master/doc/release/1.17.0-notes.rst)

This causes an exception to be raised in the following line of code:

https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/e97fe91ae99df0154664933102f03405940b86d6/obspy/core/util/misc.py#L614

which has the effect of breaking the remove_response() method of the Trace object, as demonstrated in the test script I've attached (renamed to .txt to make github happy).

The error is:

`AttributeError: module 'numpy.fft' has no attribute 'fftpack'`

[testresp.txt](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/files/3463112/testresp.txt)

OS Version: OSX 10.13.6
Python:  3.6.7
numpy: 1.17.0
obspy: 1.1.1

I created a test environment with conda:
conda create -n testfft python=3.6 obspy

The workaround, I suppose is to not use numpy 1.17 or higher until this is patched in obspy.

title: Fix reading from buffer not at start of file and using autodetection

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

milestone.description: TRFKAP  --  The release formerly known as "pre-EGU 2018 release"

body:
I am pretty sure we have a bug in our reading routines when
 - auto fileformat detection is used
 - a binary buffer is passed
 - that buffer is not at start of file

To reproduce, add some random bytes into a buffer and fill the rest with a valid waveform files data:

```python
from obspy import read
filename = 'LMOW.BHE.SAC'  # file is in io/sac/tests/data
import io
bio = io.BytesIO()
bio.write(b'123456')
data = open(filename, 'rb').read()
bio.write(data)
bio.seek(6)
st = read(bio)
```

The last line will call `_is_mseed()` first, and then goes over to `_is_sac()` and should eventually read it as a sac file starting at the initial offset position of 6 bytes.

This might be a real edge case, especially since some `is_xxx()` check routines might not be clean about keeping file handles open (did not check all of them..) but still should be fixed eventually.

The fix should be simple, but I found more code that breaks when not at position 0 in buffer (in sac file check) and there might be many more locations with problems of that kind, but still better to fix at least some of them. We probably need a `_generic_is_file_format` routine that consistently handles open file handles etc like was done in #2326 not sure..

```diff
diff --git a/obspy/core/util/base.py b/obspy/core/util/base.py
index 9c81efe17..0a9ffbcea 100644
--- a/obspy/core/util/base.py
+++ b/obspy/core/util/base.py
@@ -433,7 +434,7 @@ def _read_from_plugin(plugin_type, filename, format=None, **kwargs):
             # check format
             is_format = is_format(filename)
             if position is not None:
-                filename.seek(0, 0)
+                filename.seek(position, 0)
             if is_format:
                 break
         else:
```

title: Catalog to NLLOC_OBS: picks without time_error
body:
When converting a `Catalog` object to `NLLOC_OBS`, phase picks without a time error are given an error of `-1` (see [here](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/master/obspy/io/nlloc/core.py#L409)). 

I did some check, and I think that NonLinLoc interprets the time error always as positive, which gives a time error of one second! (pinging @alomax to be sure of that).

So, I think that the time error should be set to zero in these cases.

title: Polarization Analysis issues

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

milestone.description: TRFKAP  --  The release formerly known as "pre-EGU 2018 release"

body:
I've found a couple problems with `obspy.signal.polarization.polarization_analysis`
1) `polarization_analysis` requires parameter `frqlow` and `frqhigh` (regardless of `method`), however looking in the source code those parameters are only used if `method="vidale"`. Reading the documentation I expected these to filter the stream I pass the function. (Also I feel like these parameters should be named `freqmin` and `freqmax` in order to match the names parameters that would be passed to a bandpass filter, for example)
2) On lines 508-513 of the source code (obspy/signal/polarization.py):
```
            if "Z" in tr.stats.channel:
                z = dat.copy()
            if "N" in tr.stats.channel:
                n = dat.copy()
            if "E" in tr.stats.channel:
                e = dat.copy()
```
   I've got a channel named "ENZ", this channel will get all mixed up because all of the above instances are true (other channels like "ELZ" or "HNE" would also get mixed up). I would recommend replacing this with:
```
            if tr.stats.channel[-1] == "Z":
                z = dat.copy()
            elif tr.stats.channel[-1] == "N":
                n = dat.copy()
            elif tr.stats.channel[-1] == "E":
                e = dat.copy()
            else:
                raise NameError
```

Version info:
  -  ObsPy 1.1.0 (installed from anaconda)
  -  Python 3.6.6
  -  Ubuntu 18.04.2

Thanks for all you guys do!

body:
Dear all,

I discovered this behaviour, but I'm not sure if it's an ObsPy issue, or related to the EIDA routing or some webservice issue at INGV. It occurs only when accessing metadata that is hosted at INGV (such as e.g. the IV net, but the behavior is the same for any other net hosted at INGV).

Basically, when not specifying the level of the get_stations request, no stations are returned for any networks hosted at INGV. Only when specifying the _level_ (e.g. level='channel') stations are successfully returned. Specifying stations, locations or channels does not change the behavior. Direct requests without routing (using obspy.clients.fdsn.Client and specifying INGV) and without specifying the _level_ work fine also for any INGV hosted data.

`from obspy.clients.fdsn import RoutingClient`
`from obspy import UTCDateTime`
`routed = RoutingClient('eida-routing')`
`t1 = UTCDateTime('2016-01-01T00:00:00')`
`t2 = UTCDateTime('2019-01-01T00:00:00')`

The following line will return an empty inventory object:
`routed.get_stations(network='IV', starttime=t1, endtime=t2)`

Only when specifying the _level_ of request, it will work:
`routed.get_stations(network='IV', starttime=t1, endtime=t2, level='station')`

Again, this occurs only when requesting metadata that is hosted at INGV. Any other metadata hosted elsewhere will be successfully returned even when _level_ is not specified. Thus my confusion if it's actually related to ObsPy ...

Best regards,
Florian

title: Nordic high accuracy

milestone.description: TRFKAP  --  The release formerly known as "pre-EGU 2018 release"

body:
### What does this PR do?

Adds support for high(er)-precision timing in Nordic pick files (closes #2348) and add support for long phase names - from the seisan manual:

> Long phase names: An 8 character phase can be used in column 11-18. There is then not room for polarity information. the weight is then put into column 9. This format is recognised by HYP and MULPLT

### Why was it initiated? Any relevant Issues?
Seconds can run in columns 23-28 - I misread the indexing and was reading columns 23-28 rather than 22-28. #2348 pointed out that this is used when seisan is run in "high-accuracy" mode.

Note, pick times are now written out by default in high-accuracy from obspy now. I need to confirm that seisan is always happy with this, if not then a flag option for high-accuracy should be implemented.

title: reading of seconds on Nordic Type 4 lines

labels.name: .io
labels.description: issues generally related to our read/write plugins

milestone.description: TRFKAP  --  The release formerly known as "pre-EGU 2018 release"

body:
obspy incorrectly reads pick times (specifically seconds) when the seconds are given to millisecond precision (I assume this happens when I use high-accuracy mode, but in any case it is a "standard" output for SEISAN as can be seen in the definition of Nordic files (screenshot attached).

I have attached an example Nordic file: the first and third "events" are in this high-accuracy notation.  I have also attached a script to read this file and print out the pick times so that you can compare for yourself(ves).  I had to add the suffix "txt" so that it could be attached.

The solution is to read in line[22:28] as seconds instead of line[23:28], in obspy.io.nordic.core, I have attached a screenshot of the relevant code from the current git in which the relevant lines are 745 and 749

I am using obspy version 1.1.1, installed using conda (and conda-forge)

title: fdsn EIDA routed client: problem with spammed subprocesses (memory leak)

milestone.description: TRFKAP  --  The release formerly known as "pre-EGU 2018 release"

body:
Issue reported on the users mailing list:

```
I am facing a potential issue with the ObsPy FDSN client. I am using the EIDA
routing client to download waveform data and metadata for many stations. The 
way I do it is a simple loop over all stations, using the get_waveforms()
function in the loop. In principle it looks like this:

from obspy.clients.fdsn import RoutingClient as Client
client = Client('eida-routing')
for station in long_list :
    data = client.get_waveforms(...)
    data.write(filename)

The problem is, that each time data is actually downloaded, ObsPy seems to
start several new processes in the background, which are not being closed until
the end of the python script. Thus, for each station in the for-loop new 
additional processes are started but not closed again. Since I have a very long
stationlist and many days that I loop over, basically I end up spawning more
processes than the systen can handle, ultimately resulting in the message:
"Can't start new thread"

This problem only occurs with the fdsn routing client, but e.g. not with the 
ArcLink client. I did not try the non-routed fdsn client. Same behaviour with
ObsPy versions 1.1.0 and 1.1.1 ... 
```

title: Empty EventDescription results with text values of "None"

labels.name: .core.event
labels.description: issues related to our Catalog/Event functionality

milestone.description: TRFKAP  --  The release formerly known as "pre-EGU 2018 release"

body:
Running on current obspy master on Ubuntu 16, python 3.7

Empty `EventDescription` objects prevents a catalog from being saved to disk via quakeml and still evaluating to equal.

```python
import io
import obspy.core.event as ev
from obspy import read_events

# create a catalog  with an empty event description
empty_description = ev.EventDescription()
cat1 = read_events()
cat1[0].event_descriptions.append(empty_description)

# serialize the catalog using quakeml and re-read
bio = io.BytesIO()
cat1.write(bio, 'quakeml')
bio.seek(0)
cat2 = read_events(bio)

# the two catalog are not equal
assert cat1 == cat2 

# because one event_description has text of 'None' and the other of None
assert cat1[0].event_descriptions[-1].text == cat2[0].event_descriptions[-1].text
```

The issue is that StationXML cannot store units for gain only stages. Thus, upon reading StationXML, there is now a post-processing step to assign the units of surrounding to gain only response stages. I think this should be save and we can now round-trip these types of response stages.

title: obspy.read() unaffected by byteorder settings for SAC files
body:
I am under the impression that obspy.read() behavior seems unaffected by setting 'byteorder' settings.
For example, I was not able to load a little-endian SAC trace (created by an home-made Fortran routine of my own). Even if I tried specifying explicitely "byteorder=little" in option.
However, reformatting the same record using a big-endian byteorder using the same routine produced a file that I could load properly using obspy.read() with no option.
Note: My computer is natively ordering bytes into little-endian representation.

My conclusion is that osbpy.read() can only handle big-endian files for SAC format (independently of  byteorder option settings)

Both files are provided in attachement (same record, produced by the same routine, only byteordering differs).



[endian_read_issue_obspy.zip](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/files/2773260/endian_read_issue_obspy.zip)

title: Fix vincenty inverse for equatorial line
body:
I looked in detail the calculation of vincenty inverse to fix the unit test on Alpine (see #1825). I think that a case is not correctly handled when `cos²α = 0`. On [this website](https://www.movable-type.co.uk/scripts/latlong-vincenty.html), a note describes this case:

> Vincenty observes that eqn. (18) becomes indeterminate over equatorial lines (since cos²α → 0); in this case, set cos2σm to 0 and the result is computed correctly.

The problematic unit test calculates the distance between (0, 0) and (0, 17) which is precisely an equatorial line. Handling the `cos²α = 0` fixes this issue. Another test on the equatorial line was expected to fail (distance between (0, 0) and (0, 13)) and is converging now.

Moreover, this case is also handled in [geopy](https://github.com/geopy/geopy/blob/master/geopy/distance.py#L573) in the same way.

I also did some minor changes:

- Some cos/sin was already calculated, I reused directly the value instead of recalculating the cos/sin.
- `α` was calculated but only `cos²α` was useful, I calculated it directly without using `asin`.
- This code block was inside the loop for no reason:

```python
u2 = pow(math.cos(alpha), 2) * (a * a - b * b) / (b * b)
_a = 1 + (u2 / 16384) * (4096 + u2 * (-768 + u2 *
                                        (320 - 175 * u2)))
_b = (u2 / 1024) * (256 + u2 * (-128 + u2 * (74 - 47 * u2)))
delta_sigma = _b * sin_sigma * \
    (cos2sigma_m + (_b / 4) *
        (cos_sigma * (-1 + 2 * pow(cos2sigma_m, 2)) - (_b / 6) *
            cos2sigma_m * (-3 + 4 * sqr_sin_sigma) *
            (-3 + 4 * pow(cos2sigma_m, 2))))

dist = b * _a * (sigma - delta_sigma)
alpha12 = math.atan2(
    (math.cos(u_2) * math.sin(dlon)),
    (math.cos(u_1) * math.sin(u_2) -
        math.sin(u_1) * math.cos(u_2) * math.cos(dlon)))
alpha21 = math.atan2(
    (math.cos(u_1) * math.sin(dlon)),
    (-math.sin(u_1) * math.cos(u_2) +
        math.cos(u_1) * math.sin(u_2) * math.cos(dlon)))
```

It was useless to calculate these variables at each iteration, I moved the block at the end of the function.

title: Resource IDs can refer to wrong object when former object goes out of scope

labels.name: .core.event
labels.description: issues related to our Catalog/Event functionality

milestone.description: TRFKAP  --  The release formerly known as "pre-EGU 2018 release"

body:
Ubuntu 18.04, python 3.7, master branch of ObsPy

Currently `get_referred_object` method of the `ResourceIdentifier` can return the wrong object if the object that was bound to the `ResourceIdentifier` instance gets deleted and a new object is assigned to the same python id. [Here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20753364/why-is-the-id-of-a-python-class-not-unique-when-called-quickly) is a good SO post that demonstrates how python object ids are only unique over an object's lifetime, not over the program lifetime.

The following code demonstrates the problem:

```python
import obspy.core.event as ev

# a class to count instance creations
class Counter:
    count = 0
    def __init__(self):
        self.count = self.__class__.count
        self.__class__.count += 1

# simple setup of objects and resource IDs
rid1 = ev.ResourceIdentifier(referred_object=obj1)
rid2 = ev.ResourceIdentifier(referred_object=obj2)

# rid1 and rid2 work as expected, obj1, obj2 have the following ids
print(id(obj1), id(obj2))

# now if we delete obj1 and obj2 then create additional python objects which are
# bound to different resource ids
del obj1
del obj2
obj3, obj4 = Counter(), Counter()
rid3 = ev.ResourceIdentifier(referred_object=obj3)
rid4 = ev.ResourceIdentifier(referred_object=obj4)

#  If the python id of obj1 or obj2 id is re-used we are going to have problems...
print(id(obj3), id(obj4))

# rid3 and rid4 work as expected, of course. However, if obj3 or obj4 has the same python
# id as obj1 or obj2 then rid1 or rid2 will return the wrong object rather than None.
# So, the following will sometimes (~50% of the time) raise an AssertionError because
# obj3 or obj4 is assigned to  a python id that was previously used by obj1 or obj2
# and the object id is the key for the ResourceIdentifier._id_object_map dict
assert rid1.get_referred_object() is None
assert rid1.get_referred_object() is None
```
