title: AR picker fails for low amplitude data

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

body:
Bug occurs in:
- Current obspy master, Linux, installed from source


This issue was raised on the gitter chat by @Dieselinium_twitter. The AR picker uses floats in the internal c-func, but gives incorrect pick-times when there are low amplitudes. I haven't fully investigated this, but I suspect it is a rounding error and could be fixed by using double-precision for some internal variables in the c-func.

@Dieselinium_twitter found this case after removing instrument response from his data, resulting in low amplitude ground-motion data.

The below minimal example is adapted from the [AR-picker tutorial](https://docs.obspy.org/tutorial/code_snippets/trigger_tutorial.html#ar-picker):

```python
import numpy as np
from obspy.core import read
from obspy.signal.trigger import ar_pick


tr1 = read('https://examples.obspy.org/loc_RJOB20050801145719850.z.gse2')[0]
tr2 = read('https://examples.obspy.org/loc_RJOB20050801145719850.n.gse2')[0]
tr3 = read('https://examples.obspy.org/loc_RJOB20050801145719850.e.gse2')[0]

for tr in [tr1, tr2, tr3]:
    tr.data = tr.data * 1e-6
    tr.data = tr.data.astype(np.float32)
    tr.plot()
df = tr1.stats.sampling_rate
p_pick, s_pick = ar_pick(tr1.data, tr2.data, tr3.data, df,
                         1.0, 20.0, 1.0, 0.1, 4.0, 1.0, 2, 8, 0.1, 0.2)
print(p_pick)
```

This plots each trace, just to make sure that the data can be represented at float32 (which they can).  This outputs a p-pick time of: `-0.10000000149011612`, when it would (without the gain) output `30.6350002289`.

title: "identity stage" not correctly reproduced when writing and reading Inventory
body:
Obspy master does not write the output and input units of identity stages, i.e. stages that do nothing. As a consequence, input and output units are set to None when reading the inventory again.

```py
from obspy import read_inventory, UTCDateTime as UTC
from obspy.clients.nrl import NRL
from obspy.core.inventory import Inventory, Network, Station, Channel, Site

nrl = NRL()
sensor = ['Guralp', 'CMG-3ESP', '60 s - 50 Hz', '2000']
datalogger = ['REF TEK', 'RT 130 & 130-SMA', '1', '100']
response = nrl.get_response(datalogger, sensor)
print('original reponse')
print(response)

ch = Channel(code='HHZ', location_code='', latitude=0, longitude=0,
             elevation=0, depth=0, sample_rate=100, response=response)
st = Station(code='XX', latitude=0, longitude=0, elevation=0,
             site=Site('XX'), channels=[ch])
net = Network(code='YY', stations=[st])
inv = Inventory(networks=[net], source='me')
print('\nstill OK after creating Inventory')
print(inv.get_response('YY.XX..HHZ', UTC()))

inv.write('bug.xml', 'STATIONXML')
inv2 = read_inventory('bug.xml')
response2 = inv2.get_response('YY.XX..HHZ', UTC())
print('\nunits missing in stage 2 after writing and reading')
print(response2)
```

Output:
```
original reponse
Channel Response
	From M/S (Velocity in Meters per Second) to COUNTS (Digital Counts)
	Overall Sensitivity: 1.25932e+09 defined at 1.000 Hz
	11 stages:
		Stage 1: PolesZerosResponseStage from M/S to V, gain: 2000
		Stage 2: ResponseStage from V to V, gain: 1
		Stage 3: CoefficientsTypeResponseStage from V to COUNTS, gain: 629129
		Stage 4: CoefficientsTypeResponseStage from COUNTS to COUNTS, gain: 1
		Stage 5: CoefficientsTypeResponseStage from COUNTS to COUNTS, gain: 1

title: Bug comparing ComparingObject to an object without __dict__
body:
### Issue:
Comparing `ComparingObjects` to random objects with `==` / `__eq__` should return `False` not raise and excption.
### Actual case:
If you have 2 `Channels` one with a valid `Equipment` and the other with `None`
`chan1 == chan2` 
raises 
```
  File "/Users/lloyd/code/obspy/obspy/core/util/base.py", line 519, in __ne__
    return not self.__eq__(other)
  File "/Users/lloyd/code/obspy/obspy/core/util/base.py", line 516, in __eq__
    return self.__dict__ == other.__dict__
AttributeError: 'int' object has no attribute '__dict__'
```
The first commit only has the tests, you can pull and exersize.
### Solution:
At first I was worried about this solution breaking comparisons with other types that were compatible, e.g. `CustomComplex` == `complex`, but those kinds of types don't inherit from `ComparingObject`, and those seem to inherit from their compatible types... and the tests passed.

title: Fix get_gaps overlapping
body:
The [get_gaps](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/master/obspy/core/stream.py#L745) method isn't working as expected if a trace is completely overlapping another trace. The `starttime` of the gaps is the `endtime` of the first trace even if the `endtime` of the second trace is previous.

This little PR just tries to fix that.

title: Empty QuantityError instances changes in roundtrip to disk

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

labels.name: .core.event
labels.description: issues related to our Catalog/Event functionality

body:
obspy 1.1.0, ubuntu 16.04, python 3.6

It seems saving a simple event object to disk (with a single empty origin) and then loading causes the loaded event and original event not to evaluate to equal. For example:

```python
import obspy
import obspy.core.event as ev

# create event and save to disk
origin = ev.Origin(time=obspy.UTCDateTime('2016-01-01'))
event = ev.Event(origins=[origin])
event.write('temp.xml', 'quakeml')

# read from disk
event2 = obspy.read_events('temp.xml')[0]

# saved and loaded event should be equal
print(event2 == event)  # False

# depth_errors are no longer equal
print(event2.origins[0].depth_errors == event.origins[0].depth_errors)  # False

# event has a QuantityError with all None values and event2 has None 
print(type(event.origins[0].depth_errors))  # QuantityError
print(type(event2.origins[0].depth_errors))  # NoneType

# setting event.origins[0].depth_errors to None fixes the problem
event.origins[0].depth_errors = None
print(event == event2)  # True
```

Not sure but this may be related to #2166?

Hello,

Was advised on the mailing list to post this issue here.

I've been happily working with CSS format files generated by the Pisces package but have a small issue when trying to read them with ObsPy. Essentially, I get an unknown file format error using 'read' unless I specify what the data format is explicitly, i.e., st = read("file.wfdisc", format = "CSS"). 

Without specifying the format, the full traceback is:

--> 235             st.extend(_read(file, format, headonly, **kwargs).traces)

<decorator-gen-147> in _read(filename, format, headonly, **kwargs)

--> 211         result = func(filename, *args, **kwargs)

~/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/obspy/core/stream.py in _read(filename, format, headonly, **kwargs)

title: Change dummy time.strptime call to use locale-independent format #2147
body: Fixes #2147

title: FDSN routing client has a locale dependency
body:
There's a dummy call to `time.strptime` in the module init that uses locale-specific formatting, which fails under locales that don't use the same names (ie. "Nov" for the 11th month of the year).

```
>>> import locale
>>> locale.setlocale(locale.LC_TIME, ('zh_CN', 'UTF-8'))
'zh_CN.UTF-8'
>>> from obspy.clients.fdsn.routing.routing_client import RoutingClient
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/workspace/anaconda/envs/django/lib/python2.7/site-packages/obspy/clients/fdsn/__init__.py", line 242, in <module>
    from .routing.routing_client import RoutingClient  # NOQA
  File "/workspace/anaconda/envs/django/lib/python2.7/site-packages/obspy/clients/fdsn/routing/__init__.py", line 25, in <module>
    time.strptime("30 Nov 00", "%d %b %y")
  File "/workspace/anaconda/envs/django/lib/python2.7/_strptime.py", line 478, in _strptime_time
    return _strptime(data_string, format)[0]
  File "/workspace/anaconda/envs/django/lib/python2.7/_strptime.py", line 332, in _strptime
    (data_string, format))
ValueError: time data u'30 Nov 00' does not match format u'%d %b %y'
```

I believe switching this to an ISO8601-like string would be locale-agnostic:

    time.strptime("2000/11/30", "%Y/%m/%d")

title: FDSN client: bug in Client.set_credentials() (not using queryauth endpoint)
body:
There is a bug in FDSN client (current `maintenance_1.1.x`) when providing credentials via `Client.set_credentials()` (as opposed to providing credentials during `Client.__init__()`). Reported on the mailing list: https://lists.swapbytes.de/archives/obspy-users/2018-May/002749.html

+TESTS:clients.fdsn

### Works:
```python
from obspy.clients.fdsn import Client

client = Client(base_url="IRIS", user="nobody@iris.edu",
                password="anonymous")
print(client._build_url("dataselect", "query", {'net': "BW"}))
```
```
http://service.iris.edu/fdsnws/dataselect/1/queryauth?net=BW
```
### Also works:
```python
from obspy.clients.fdsn import Client

client = Client(base_url="IRIS", user="dummy")
client.set_credentials(user="nobody@iris.edu", password="anonymous")
print(client._build_url("dataselect", "query", {'net': "BW"}))
```
```
http://service.iris.edu/fdsnws/dataselect/1/queryauth?net=BW
```


### Does not work:
```python
from obspy.clients.fdsn import Client

client = Client(base_url="IRIS")
client.set_credentials(user="nobody@iris.edu", password="anonymous")
print(client._build_url("dataselect", "query", {'net': "BW"}))
```
```
http://service.iris.edu/fdsnws/dataselect/1/query?net=BW
```

title: Fallback to linear interpolation for instable bullen slowness evaluation
Infer sampling rates for each response stage + Support for PAZ without decimation attributes

labels.name: .core.inventory
labels.description: issues related to our Inventory functionality

body:
This PR adds a new method `.get_sampling_rates()` to calculate the input and output sampling rates of each response stage. For most responses it will just parse the decimation attributes. For those with missing information it will infer the sampling rates from the surrounding stages.

```python
>>> import obspy
>>> inv = obspy.read_inventory("AU.MEEK.xml")
>>> inv[0][0][0].response.get_sampling_rates()
{1: {'decimation_factor': 1,
     'input_sampling_rate': 600.0,
     'output_sampling_rate': 600.0},
 2: {'decimation_factor': 1,
     'input_sampling_rate': 600.0,
     'output_sampling_rate': 600.0},
 3: {'decimation_factor': 1,
     'input_sampling_rate': 600.0,
     'output_sampling_rate': 600.0},
 4: {'decimation_factor': 3,
     'input_sampling_rate': 600.0,
     'output_sampling_rate': 200.0},
 5: {'decimation_factor': 10,
     'input_sampling_rate': 200.0,
     'output_sampling_rate': 20.0}}
```

Additionally it will now add dummy decimation attributes to PAZ stages without set decimation attributes as evalresp does not like that. Fixes #2121.

I realize that this adds a new method but it also fixes a but so I guess the maintance branch is okay here.

@Permian Can you also give this a quick review?

title: A problem with Obspy on Raspbery PI -- mseed write -- solved (ish)

labels.name: DEB
labels.description: issues related to Debian/Ubuntu packaging / packages

labels.name: packaging
labels.description: issue related to our packaging efforts (e.g. conda, Debian, ...)

body:
Hi
I have had problems running obspy (python3) on a raspberry pi leading to error messages such as
ValueError: /usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/obspy/core/util/../../lib/libmseed_Linux_32bit_py34.cpython-34m.so: undefined symbol: LM_SIZEOF_OFF_T. Here I am trying to write in mseed format

This can be solved by renaming all the files in /usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/obspy/lib/ to omit the "-arm-linux-gnueabihf" element of their filenames

i.e. 
"sudo cp /usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/obspy/lib/libmseed_Linux_32bit_py34.cpython-34m-arm-linux-gnueabihf.so                                                                                                                                           /usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/obspy/lib/libmseed_Linux_32bit_py34.cpython-34m.so "
 

and so on for the others in the directory

Trust this is of some help

Ian

title: Mass downloader fixes
body:
This fixes a couple of issues with the mass downloader. Most of them originated when channels had a number of short epochs which it did not cleanly handle. Additionally it catches another error class as discovered in #2079 .

It includes a version of #1870 but also fixes the root cause of the whole thing so it should no longer be necessary. But better safe than sorry.

Fixes #2079 and #1870.

title: SEG-Y Doc not correct
body:
The documentation for [obspy.io.segy.segy.iread_segy](http://docs.obspy.org/packages/autogen/obspy.io.segy.segy.iread_segy.html#obspy.io.segy.segy.iread_segy) states that `headonly = True` makes data unpacking on the fly available.

> headonly (bool)
> Determines whether or not the actual data records will be read and unpacked. Has a huge impact on memory usage. Data can be read and unpacked on-the-fly after reading the file. Defaults to False.

This seems incorrect. This seems to refer to #386 and #388. These are a little confusing due to trac2github, therefore I could determine the correct header without bugging @krischer directly (thanks again).

The correct headerword should be `unpack_headers` this should be reflected correctly in the docs.

body:
Hi
I use the latest obspy under python 3.6.0 and CentOS 6.9 x64:
```
$ python --version
Python 3.6.0 :: Anaconda custom (64-bit)
$ lsb_release -a
LSB Version:	:base-4.0-amd64:base-4.0-noarch:core-4.0-amd64:core-4.0-noarch
Distributor ID:	CentOS
Description:	CentOS release 6.9 (Final)

Codename:	Final
```

I try to download waveform of DK.DY2G using following python script:
```
import obspy
from obspy.clients.fdsn.mass_downloader import RectangularDomain, \
    Restrictions, MassDownloader
import os

domain = RectangularDomain(minlatitude=60, maxlatitude=80,
                           minlongitude=-75, maxlongitude=-15)

restrictions = Restrictions(
    
    starttime=obspy.UTCDateTime(2012, 1, 1, 0, 0, 0),
    endtime=obspy.UTCDateTime(2012, 2, 1, 0, 0, 0),
    
    network="DK", channel="BHZ", station="DY2G", location="01",
    reject_channels_with_gaps=False,
    sanitize=True,
    minimum_length=0.0,
    minimum_interstation_distance_in_m=100.0)

mdl = MassDownloader(providers=["IRIS"])
def get_mseed_storage(network, station, location, channel, starttime, endtime):

mseed_storage = get_mseed_storage
tt = mdl.download(domain, restrictions, mseed_storage, stationxml_storage="stations")

title: [MassDownloader] Let the 'channel' and 'location' settings override the priority lists
body:
### What does this PR do?

This makes the code works as documented, that is: if the `channel` variable is set, then the `channel_priorities` list is ignored. The same goes for the `location` variable and `location_priorities`.

### Why was it initiated?  Any relevant Issues?

Yes: the code was not working as documented (and the documented behavior makes sense).

title: Ndk bugfix
body:
Line 3 must be treated as fixed-width fields because otherwise parsing fails for a few ndk's where there is no space between the centroid time and its error, like e.g. in event C110397G.

To test this:
```
wget 'http://www.ldeo.columbia.edu/~gcmt/projects/CMT/catalog/jan76_dec13.ndk'
python -c 'import obspy; obspy.read_events("jan76_dec13.ndk")'
```
This produced several errors but now works.

title: StationXML write dates before 1900
body: Fixes #2013 also on Python 2.7.

title: bugfix CNV write, fixes #2001
body:
Passing ``phase_mapping`` to ``Catalog.write(format="CNV", phase_mapping=...)`` resulted in an exception.

Bugfix #2001 

This https://github.com/obspy/obspy/issues/2009 is not linked but could be part of the same PR?

title: seishub: authentication check not working

milestone.description: Next major release, dropping Python 2 support and being the first Python 3 only release.

body:
The authentication check `Client.test_auth()` seems broken and always returns `True`. Probably not worth fixing given that seishub kind of is replaced by [jane](http://github.com/krischer/jane).

CC @trichter

title: CNV writing phase_mapping fails
body:
This line:
https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/master/obspy/io/cnv/core.py#L63

doesn't work because 

``values.update(("P", "S"))`` returns ``None``

This works:
```python
values = set(phase_mapping.values())
values.update(("P","S"))
    if values != set(("P", "S")):

```

title: Bug in reading SC3ML (assumes optional maxClockDrift is always present)

labels.name: .io
labels.description: issues generally related to our read/write plugins

body:
There is a bug in reading SC3ML station metadata into Inventory. It is assumed that `maxClockDrift` is always present, but it's optional in SC3ML. First reported on users mailing list: http://lists.swapbytes.de/archives/obspy-users/2017-November/002578.html

I changed the test data so that the bug shows with current tests.

@Jollyfant can you have a look since you implemented SC3ML -> Inventory?

title: pickling SOH traces
body:
These raise a division by zero Exception:
Which prevents pickling traces.

```
from obspy.core import Stats, Trace
import pickle

s = Stats()
s.delta = 0    

t = Trace()
t.stats.sampling_rate = 0
pickle.loads(pickle.dumps(t))
```
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ZeroDivisionError                         Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-7-c105e6dd98fb> in <module>()
----> 1 pickle.loads(pickle.dumps(t))

~/code/obspy/obspy/core/util/attribdict.py in __setstate__(self, adict)
    113         self.__dict__.update(self.defaults)
    114         # update with pickle dictionary
--> 115         self.update(adict)
    116 
    117     def __getattr__(self, name, default=None):

~/code/obspy/obspy/core/util/attribdict.py in update(self, adict)
    140             if key in self.readonly:
    141                 continue
--> 142             self.__setitem__(key, value)
    143 
    144     def _pretty_str(self, priorized_keys=[], min_label_length=16):

~/code/obspy/obspy/core/trace.py in __setitem__(self, key, value)
    159             if key == 'delta':
    160                 key = 'sampling_rate'
--> 161                 value = 1.0 / float(value)
    162             elif key == 'sampling_rate':
    163                 value = float(value)

ZeroDivisionError: float division by zero
```

title: mseed: Avoid invalid warning when guessing endianness of timestamps / UTCDateTime: proper exceptions on invalid 'julday'

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

body:
mseed: avoid showing invalid warnings when guessing endian during
    parsing time stamps
    
    so far, if during parsing a timestamp the endian is not known beforehand
    and if the wrong endian is tried first, a warning message about
    invalid fractional seconds gets shown which is a bogus warning
    
    also, internally we simply rely on UTCDateTime.__init__() raising any
    exception whatsoever for endian detection. this adds some sanity by
    checking if the julday is in between 1-366 (which is the range accepted
    by UTCDateTime.__init__)

---

    utcdatetime: add proper sanity checks for UTCDateTime(..., julday=..)
    
    right now passing invalid juldays can result in misleading error messages, because
    julday is silently discarded when encountering out-of-bounds values that
    internally in datetime.datetime.strptime(..., '%Y%j') raise "ValueError:
    unconverted data remains:"
    
    In [1]: UTCDateTime(year=2017, julday=367)
    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
    <ipython-input-1-0e1465633d82> in <module>()
    ----> 1 UTCDateTime(year=2017, julday=367)
    
    /home/megies/git/obspy-master/obspy/core/utcdatetime.py in __init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
        357             kwargs['microsecond'] = int(round(_frac * 1e6))
        358             args = args[0:5]
    --> 359         dt = datetime.datetime(*args, **kwargs)
        360         self._from_datetime(dt)
        361
    
    TypeError: Required argument 'month' (pos 2) not found
    
This changes this to:
    
    In [1]: UTCDateTime(year=2017, julday=367)
    ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
    ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
    <ipython-input-1-0e1465633d82> in <module>()
    ----> 1 UTCDateTime(year=2017, julday=367)
    
    /home/megies/git/obspy-master/obspy/core/utcdatetime.py in __init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
        342             if not (0 <= int(kwargs['julday']) <= 366):
        343                 msg = "'julday' out of bounds: {!s}".format(kwargs['julday'])
    --> 344                 raise ValueError(msg)
        345             if 'year' in kwargs:
        346                 # year given as kwargs
    
    ValueError: 'julday' out of bounds: 367


no time to add tests right now, sorry..

title: Fix URLs with invalid symbols

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

labels.name: .core.event
labels.description: issues related to our Catalog/Event functionality

labels.name: .core.inventory
labels.description: issues related to our Inventory functionality

body: We used the URLs to download files with the `read_X()` methods to determine the suffix of the temporary files. This could result in invalid characters being part of the filenames. This should be fixed with this PR.

title: Routing to fdsnws sub domains
body:
Fixes #1954.

Discovered as at least the IRIS federator now also routes to the raspberryshake fdsnws service. I also applied the same fix to the eida router as it was wrong in both.

title: Bug in new FDSN RoutingClient?
body:
Looks ike we might have a bug in the routing client:  (this is on 1.1.0rc7)

```python
import obspy
from obspy.clients.fdsn import RoutingClient

client = RoutingClient('iris-federator', debug=True)

t = obspy.UTCDateTime(2017, 10, 20)

inv = client.get_stations(
    level="station", starttime=t,
    latitude=30, longitude=14, maxradius=10)  
inv.plot()
print(inv)
```

title: trace.Trace should not change the header

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

body:
Basic info
  -  ObsPy version 1.0.3
  - Python version: 3.6
  - Platform: Windows 10

I found a problem when I was using trace.Trace to initialize a trace object. Codes are listed bellow

```python
    from obspy.core import trace
    import numpy as np
    data = [0] * 20
    header = {
        'station': 'MS',
        'starttime': None
    }
    header['starttime'] = 1
    my_trace1 = trace.Trace(data=np.array(data), header=header)
    print(my_trace1)
    data = [1] * 60
    my_trace2= trace.Trace(data=np.array(data), header=header)
    print(my_trace2)
    print(header)
```
Then I got:

```
.MS.. | 1970-01-01T00:00:01.000000Z - 1970-01-01T00:00:20.000000Z | 1.0 Hz, 20 samples
.MS.. | 1970-01-01T00:00:01.000000Z - 1970-01-01T00:00:20.000000Z | 1.0 Hz, 20 samples
{'station': 'MS', 'starttime': 1, 'npts': 20}
```

I used this script to initialize two sets of traces. What I expected of `my_trace2` is a trace of 60 samples, but I got 20. I browsed the source code of trace and found a possible reason. When Trace is initialized, the `header` would be set a default key `npts`, therefore, the sample number of `my_trace2` is not correct when I use `header` the second time.

```python
    def __init__(self, data=np.array([]), header=None):
        # make sure Trace gets initialized with suitable ndarray as self.data
        # otherwise we could end up with e.g. a list object in self.data
        _data_sanity_checks(data)
        # set some defaults if not set yet
        if header is None:
            header = {}
        header.setdefault('npts', len(data))
        self.stats = Stats(header)
        # set data without changing npts in stats object (for headonly option)
        super(Trace, self).__setattr__('data', data)
```

In my opinion, an appropriate solution is to insert a line `header = header.copy()` before `header.setdefault('npts', len(data))`.

title: Bug in rotate2zne with non-orthogonal components

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

body:
obspy version: 1.0.3
installed with anaconda
According to the documentation, rotate2zne works explicitly also for non orthogonal systems. Looking into the source code, I realized, that for the basis transformation from an arbitrary system (u v w) to (z n e), the **transposed** basis vector matrix is taken. In my opinion, the **inverse** matrix must be taken.
For the transformation from one orthogonal system to another orthogonal system, the transposed matrix is equal to the inverse matrix. But in general, for non orthogonal systems, this is not the case. 
I will run some test on this issue and let you know about the results, soon.

title: QuakeML: fix a bug in reading QuakeML (empty stub MomentTensor added)
body: Reading an event with focal mechanism without moment tensor introduces an empty stub moment tensor (instead of keeping it None), which in turn can result in invalid QuakeML files when saving again later.

title: Failure to read underline "_" character from dataless file
body:
In the attached dataless file ([UP_BACU_HH.dataless.zip](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/files/1303020/UP_BACU_HH.dataless.zip)) the site_name field in blockette 50 holds the string "T3930_b A6689 3930" as can be verified by opening the file using [pdcc](http://ds.iris.edu/ds/nodes/dmc/software/downloads/pdcc/), however running 

    from obspy.io.xseed import Parser
    print Parser("UP_BACU_HH.dataless").blockettes[50][0].site_name

outputs "T3930 b A6689 3930". 

Note that also writing strings with the underline character to a dataless file also fails (sorry, no simple code-snippet available here). 

(running obspy 1.0.3 on open suse installed via pip a few months ago)

title: FDSN mass downloader: avoid duplicate filenames in download_and_split_mseed_bulk
body:
### What does this PR do?

When mass downloading it happens to me to get this kind of error
```
[...]
  File "/home/legovini/obspy/obspy/clients/fdsn/mass_downloader/utils.py", line 178, in get_filename
    raise NotImplementedError
NotImplementedError
```
Having a look to `utils.py` shows that it fails when there are more than two file candidates:
```
elif len(candidates) >= 2:
    raise NotImplementedError
````
so I took a look to these candidates and discovered that I've got three of them, but they're all identical:
```
[{'starttime': UTCDateTime(2010, 11, 27, 0, 0), 'endtime': UTCDateTime(2010, 11, 28, 0, 0), 'filename': 'waveforms/2010.331/YT.DUFK..LHZ.D.2010.331', 'current_latest_endtime': None, 'sequence
_number': None}, {'starttime': UTCDateTime(2010, 11, 27, 0, 0), 'endtime': UTCDateTime(2010, 11, 28, 0, 0), 'filename': 'waveforms/2010.331/YT.DUFK..LHZ.D.2010.331', 'current_latest_endtime':
 None, 'sequence_number': None}, {'starttime': UTCDateTime(2010, 11, 27, 0, 0), 'endtime': UTCDateTime(2010, 11, 28, 0, 0), 'filename': 'waveforms/2010.331/YT.DUFK..LHZ.D.2010.331', 'current_
latest_endtime': None, 'sequence_number': None}]
```

The most logical thing seems to discard identical candidates before `get_filename()` is called. This patch does just that.

title: Windows cache (again) - jupyter notebook issue

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

body:
Hey @barsch ,

Found a small issue with your latest changes in master for the CatchOutput stuff:
when loading obspy from jupyter notebook :
``type(sys.stdout) == <class 'ipykernel.iostream.OutStream'>``
and ``sys.stdout`` doesn't have any ``buffer`` attribute.

My workaround just adds a check that ``buffer`` exists, if not, returns.

Not sure it's the safest way of doing... But works for me.

```python
def _py36_windowsconsoleio_workaround():
    """
    This monkey patch prevents crashing Py3.6 under Windows while using
    the SuppressOutput context manager.

    Python 3.6 implemented unicode console handling for Windows. This works
    by reading/writing to the raw console handle using
    ``{Read,Write}ConsoleW``.
    The problem is that we are going to ``dup2`` over the stdio file
    descriptors when doing ``FDCapture`` and this will ``CloseHandle`` the
    handles used by Python to write to the console. Though there is still some
    weirdness and the console handle seems to only be closed randomly and not
    on the first call to ``CloseHandle``, or maybe it gets reopened with the
    same handle value when we suspend capturing.
    The workaround in this case will reopen stdio with a different fd which
    also means a different handle by replicating the logic in
    "Py_lifecycle.c:initstdio/create_stdio".
    See https://github.com/pytest-dev/py/issues/103

    See http://bugs.python.org/issue30555
    """
    if not WIN32 or sys.version_info[:2] < (3, 6):
        return

    if not hasattr(sys.stdout, 'buffer'):
        return
    
    buffered = hasattr(sys.stdout.buffer, 'raw')
    raw_stdout = sys.stdout.buffer.raw if buffered else sys.stdout.buffer

    if not isinstance(raw_stdout, io._WindowsConsoleIO):
        return

    def _reopen_stdio(f, mode):
        if not buffered and mode[0] == 'w':
            buffering = 0
        else:
            buffering = -1

        return io.TextIOWrapper(
            open(os.dup(f.fileno()), mode, buffering),
            f.encoding,
            f.errors,
            f.newlines,
            f.line_buffering)

    sys.__stdin__ = sys.stdin = _reopen_stdio(sys.stdin, 'rb')
    sys.__stdout__ = sys.stdout = _reopen_stdio(sys.stdout, 'wb')
    sys.__stderr__ = sys.stderr = _reopen_stdio(sys.stderr, 'wb')
```

Even thought some code exists to detect SeisAn format 6 it is not properly detected under Python 3.6 (and likely others).  Detection via the internal _get_version() is fixed by adding the bytes literal declaration to the 'P' constant, i.e. `b'P'`, so

if data[0:2] == b'KP' and data[82:83] == b'P':

But then it seams that this version of the format is not supported for reading.  I do not have time at the moment to investigate what it would take to add this support so I attach an example test file for someone else or a future me to use as a reference.

title: rel_calib_stack: fix bug when using non-default windowing overlap fraction

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

body:
In `signal.calibration.rel_calib_stack` there's a bug in spectrum scaling when using a non-default window overlap fraction (default is `0.5`, i.e. 50% overlap). This bug has been in there from the very beginning. So, **all calculations ever made using this function with non-default overlap fraction are wrong.**

Here's a plot from the regression test I added, showing how spectra are offset for different choices of window overlap fraction:

![figure_1-1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1842780/27385608-90ca7f3e-5693-11e7-9ed6-13ac74253246.png)


The reason was that computation of how many windows will be computed did not account for used overlap. Fix is trivial, as the FFT helper routine returns all individual FFTs, we can just look at the shape of the FFT result.

I'll add a regression test and a fix.

title: Docs and tutorial state that output of paz_to_freq_resp should be manipulated to get the phase - really?

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

labels.name: docs
labels.description: issues that only affect the content of documentation pages, docstrings etc

body:
[Docs](https://docs.obspy.org/master/packages/autogen/obspy.signal.invsim.paz_to_freq_resp.html)
[Tutorial](https://docs.obspy.org/tutorial/code_snippets/frequency_response.html)

The doc states:

Note
In order to plot/calculate the phase you need to multiply the complex part by -1. This results from the different definition of the Fourier transform and the phase. The numpy.fft is defined as A(jw) = int_{-inf}^{+inf} a(t) e^{-jwt}; where as the analytic signal is defined A(jw) = | A(jw) | e^{jphi}. That is in order to calculate the phase the complex conjugate of the signal needs to be taken. E.g. phi = angle(f,conj(h),deg=True) As the range of phi is from -pi to pi you could add 2*pi to the negative values in order to get a plot from [0, 2pi]: where(phi<0,phi+2*pi,phi); plot(f,phi)

But `paz_to_freq_resp` never uses `numpy.fft`, rather `scipy.freqs`. Also the phase in the tutorial plot should go the other way round from `+` to `-`, shouldn't it?

title: build_taup_model fails with simple regional model
body:
Installed ObsPy v1.0.3 on Ubuntu 16.04 using Anaconda with python 3.4.5.

A simplistic 2-layer model file [cn01.tvel](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/files/955726/cn01.tvel.txt):
```
CN01 - P: Stevens, Milne, Wetmiller, & Horner (1972) Canadian Earthquakes - 1966
CN01 - S: 
    0.000      6.2000      3.5700      2.7200
   36.000      6.2000      3.5700      2.7200
   36.000      8.2000      4.7000      3.3198
 6371.000      8.2000      4.7000      3.3198
```

Produces the following error using `obspy.taup.taup_create.build_taup_model`:

``` ipython
In [1]: from obspy.taup.taup_create import build_taup_model
In [2]: build_taup_model('cn01.tvel')
Building obspy.taup model for 'cn01.tvel' ...
Traceback (most recent call last):

  File "<ipython-input-7-0f8429869a68>", line 1, in <module>
    build_taup_model('cn01.tvel')

  File "/home/nackerle/anaconda3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/obspy/taup/taup_create.py", line 181, in build_taup_model
    mod_create.run()

  File "/home/nackerle/anaconda3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/obspy/taup/taup_create.py", line 121, in run
    self.tau_model = self.create_tau_model(self.v_mod)

  File "/home/nackerle/anaconda3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/obspy/taup/taup_create.py", line 86, in create_tau_model
    _DEFAULT_VALUES["slowness_tolerance"])

  File "/home/nackerle/anaconda3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/obspy/taup/slowness_model.py", line 76, in __init__
    self.create_sample()

  File "/home/nackerle/anaconda3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/obspy/taup/slowness_model.py", line 153, in create_sample
    self.find_critical_points()

  File "/home/nackerle/anaconda3/lib/python3.4/site-packages/obspy/taup/slowness_model.py", line 440, in find_critical_points
    self.radius_of_planet, len(self.v_mod), -1, -1)

IndexError: index 2 is out of bounds for axis 0 with size 2
```

Yet same model file works fine with java TauP-2.4.3.

``` bash
$ taup_create -tvel CN01.tvel
TauP_Create starting...
Done!
$ taup_time -mod cn01 -h 18 -deg 1

Model: CN01
Distance   Depth   Phase   Travel    Ray Param  Takeoff  Incident  Purist    Purist
  (deg)     (km)   Name    Time (s)  p (s/deg)   (deg)    (deg)   Distance   Name 
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    1.00    18.0   p         18.14    17.678     98.71    80.29     1.00   = p    
    1.00    18.0   Pn        19.20    13.484     48.93    48.75     1.00   = Pn   
    1.00    18.0   PcP       19.88    16.069     63.96    63.64     1.00   = PcP  
    1.00    18.0   s         31.51    30.701     98.71    80.29     1.00   = s    
    1.00    18.0   Sn        33.39    23.525     49.24    49.05     1.00   = Sn   
    1.00    18.0   ScS       34.53    27.907     63.96    63.64     1.00   = ScS  
```
A workaround when using  `obspy.taup.taup_create.build_taup_model` is to add an extra layer at any depth between 36 km and the earth's radius. The output is then:

``` ipython
In [3]: build_taup_model('cn01.tvel')
Building obspy.taup model for 'cn01.tvel' ...

In [4]: from obspy.taup import TauPyModel

In [5]: model = TauPyModel('cn01')

In [6]: for arrival in model.get_travel_times(18, 1):
   ...:    print(arrival)
p phase arrival at 18.143 seconds
Pn phase arrival at 19.202 seconds
PcP phase arrival at 19.884 seconds
sP phase arrival at 22.054 seconds
ScP phase arrival at 23.029 seconds
PcS phase arrival at 26.410 seconds
s phase arrival at 31.509 seconds
Sn phase arrival at 33.395 seconds
ScS phase arrival at 34.533 seconds
```

My expectation, however, is that anything which works with the java TauP toolkit should work with `obspy.taup`.

Is there a better way to implement simple local and regional velocity models using `obspy.taup` and/or the java TauP toolkit? It would be nice to be able to suppress the nonsensical core phases, for example.

title: arclink.Client.get_inventory: useless routing request / fails for StationGroups (virtual networks)
body:
Obspy version 1.0.2 (no change for module .clients.arclink documented)
Python version 3.5.3
Platform: macOX 10.10.5 (14F2315)
Package manager: MacPorts

I realized this because I tried to get an inventory for a Virtual network (Station Group in Seiscomp3 terminology). 

Apparently, the `get_inventory` method requests routing information first, before it requests the inventory itself. (1) To my understanding the routing request is useless, because in an Arclink federation (EIDA) the Inventory of all nodes should have been synchronized. If synchronization fails, it also does for the routing information. (2) For Station Groups no routing information is available so this step fails completely.

I therefore suggest to eliminate the routing request completely. It is useful only for data requests (`get_waveforms`), while `get_inventory` and `get_routing` are at the same level. 

If someone really thinks routing for `get_inventory` might be somehow useful, we should set the default to `route=False`. But honestly, I'd rather opt for complete removal because do not see any utility.

Example:
```
from obspy.clients.arclink import Client

client = Client(user="peter.danecek", institution="INGV", debug=True)
client.get_inventory(network="_NFOVRANC")
```

Error:
```
ArcLinkException: Could not find route to _NFOVRANC.*. If you think the data should be there, you might want to retry with manually connecting to a different ArcLink node (see docstring of Client) to see if there is a problem with a routing table at a specific ArcLink node (and contact the ArcLink node operators).
```

Fix:
```
client.get_inventory(network="_NFOVRANC", route=False)

title: missing mandatory items in SEGYFile._write_textual_header(...)
body:
Linux, Obspy 1.0.2 installed via pip

Hi 

The textual header in a SEGY file have two mandatory entries namely the revision number (same as in bytes 301-302 of the 400 byte binary file header) and the text "C40 END TEXTUAL HEADER" (or alternatively "C40 END EBCDIC") 

It would be neat if this were automatically set by SEGYFile._write_textual_header(...), especially in the case where the textual header is not pre-set but created blank inside the function.

Not sure if the format of the revision number is mandatory, but the documentation in SEG Y rev 1 (table 1 in http://www.seg.org/Portals/0/SEG/News%20and%20Resources/Technical%20Standards/seg_y_rev1.pdf) suggest to set it in record 39 (bytes 3040-3120) on the format "C39 SEG Y REV 1"

Actually the fact that these two pieces of information are mandatory is only mentioned in footnote 6 (see table 1 and page 6 in pdf file linked to above) hence can easily be overlooked

title: UTCDateTime with matplotlib's date2num

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

body:
I observed some strange behaviour of `UTCDateTime` together with matplotlib's `date2num` function:
With matplotlib 1.5.2, obspy 1.0.3 and python2.7

```
In [1]: from matplotlib.dates import date2num
In [2]: from obspy import UTCDateTime
In [3]: date2num(UTCDateTime('2017-03-13T12:00:00.00Z'))
Out[3]: 736401.0
In [4]: date2num(UTCDateTime('2017-03-13T12:00:00.00Z').datetime)
Out[4]: 736401.5
```
if I don't convert the `UTCDateTime` object into a `datetime` object, the output is rounded down to the beginning of the day.

With matplotlib 2.0, obspy 1.0.3 and python3.5 `date2num` fails with `TypeError: 'datetime.date' object is not callable` if I don't convert the `UTCDateTime` object into a `datetime` object.

Cheers,
Yannik

title: fdsn/get_stations_bulk cross-implemented with fdsn/get_waveforms_bulk

labels.name: docs
labels.description: issues that only affect the content of documentation pages, docstrings etc

body:
Hi, this is something I noticed while doing background research for the IRIS federator project. It persists in the current master branch, and it looks like it is in the maintenance branch, too.

The documentation for **obspy.clients.fdsn.client.Client.get_stations_bulk** contains the parameter list for `get_waveforms_bulk`, such as `quality`, `minimumlength`, `longestonly`, and `attach_response`.

Also, the function itself checks for the existence of "dataselect" in services instead of "station".

Cheers,
Celso

title: Master broken for older distros

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

labels.name: packaging
labels.description: issue related to our packaging efforts (e.g. conda, Debian, ...)

body: This commit dbf73680b3e3a631f99f0c3cc88100a2394eff4d on master breaks obspy on older distros. It was discovered because for some PRs (e.g. #1670) not all docker testbot containers are able to send test reports which leads to the confusing situation that docker testbot commit status is "red" while the corresponding link to test reports at tests.obspy.org shows only "green" reports (but way fewer than the docker testbot runs containers). Please fix @krischer and next time check out docker testbot status before merging.. ;-)

title: Run test suite for obspy/scripts and fix test cases

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

labels.name: scripts
labels.description: issues related to our command line scripts

body:
In some cases I get problems with `obspy-print` command line script, seemingly because of the filename `print.py`.

One case is that `py.test` is complaining and can't execute the tests:
```
$ py.test $OBSPY/scripts/tests/test_print.py
============================================================================= test session starts ==============================================================================
platform linux2 -- Python 2.7.12, pytest-3.0.3, py-1.4.31, pluggy-0.4.0
rootdir: /home/megies/git/obspy-maintenance_1.0.x, inifile: 
collected 0 items / 1 errors 

==================================================================================== ERRORS ====================================================================================
______________________________________________________________ ERROR collecting obspy/scripts/tests/test_print.py ______________________________________________________________
ImportError while importing test module '/home/megies/git/obspy-maintenance_1.0.x/obspy/scripts/tests/test_print.py'.
Original error message:
'No module named scripts.print'
Make sure your test modules/packages have valid Python names.
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Interrupted: 1 errors during collection !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
=========================================================================== 1 error in 0.86 seconds ============================================================================
```

Another case when installing obspy and running `obspy-print` on command line didn't work because `pkg_resources` was complaining during lookup of the fail from the entry point (with a similar error as pytest shows above), but I can't reproduce it anymore right now..


So.. I think we should rename `print.py`, maybe to `print_script.py` or something else, should not be a problem as I don't think anybody is doing an import like `from obspy.scripts.print import ..` because there's really not much interesting in there..

title: PICKLE format broken / seishub client broken (unpickling of new nanosecond based utcdatetime)

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

body:
I think #1325 broke `clients.seishub`, because data is sent as pickled streams from the server and the data from the server is lacking `_ns` attribute then...

I can't see a way to fix this right now, as we can't make sure seishub server and client are on the same page UTCDateTime-wise..

title: seishub: fix `event.get_list()` kwargs `first_pick` and `last_pick`
body:
Query parameters `first_pick` and `last_pick` are only used as `min_...`
and `max_...` on server side so these kwargs were just wrong..

Should be good to go.

title: Segfault after obspy.read

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

body:
Hi devs, running the QC we are sometimes running in to a segfault reading the record headers of some files. It's been quite a challenge but I traced it back to the `obspy.read` subroutine... it really blows my mind.

    from obspy import read
    from obspy.io.mseed.util import get_flags

    # Reading the file before getting the records causes a segfault
    # when getting header flags.
    read("broken_records.mseed")
    get_flags("broken_records.mseed")

    >>> Warning: Number of blockettes in fixed header (2) does not match the number parsed (1)
    >>> Segmentation fault (core dumped)

When we do not read the file first the segmentation fault does not occur.:

    from obspy import read
    from obspy.io.mseed.util import get_flags

    get_flags("broken_records.mseed")

    >>> Warning: Number of blockettes in fixed header (2) does not match the number parsed (1)
    >>> Warning: Number of blockettes in fixed header (2) does not match the number parsed (1)
    >>> ... identical for all 16 records

Here is the file: `ftp://www.orfeus-eu.org/pub/outgoing/broken_records.mseed` (8 kb).

Thanks for the help and hope you understand this behaviour better than me..

title: mseed: Fix bytes to str compare with bytes.decode()
body:
This PR fixes a problem setting the miniseed fixed header flags when using Python 3. They are not getting set due to the fact that the Trace ID matching logic is comparing bytes with str, which will fail  in Python 3.

This PR also fixes the test that failed to detect this problem due to a similar problem in the testing code. No miniseed records were actually getting tested (python 3 only) because the requested Trace IDs were not matching those in the test file due to bytes to str comparisons.

I did not see an existing issue that seemed related, so I don't believe this affects any open issues.

I first fixed the broken test to confirm that it would fail, which it did.

```
----------------------------------------------------------------------
FAIL: test_set_flags_in_fixed_header (obspy.io.mseed.tests.test_mseed_util.MSEEDUtilTestCase)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/dauerbach/anaconda3/envs/idadcc/lib/python3.5/site-packages/obspy/io/mseed/tests/test_mseed_util.py", line 681, in test_set_flags_in_fixed_header
    512)
  File "/Users/dauerbach/anaconda3/envs/idadcc/lib/python3.5/site-packages/obspy/io/mseed/tests/test_mseed_util.py", line 832, in _check_values
    "Expected bytes")
AssertionError: b'\x15(\x88' != b'\x05(\x88' : Expected bytes

----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1359 tests in 208.915s

FAILED (failures=1)
```

After fixing `_check_values()` all tests passed and the header flags were getting set.

I do not have a Python 2 env set up and have only tested in Python 3.5 (Conda installed, OS X 10.12).

Hopefully I haven't missed anything... :)

Cheers,
Dan

title: seishub client: avoid auto type casting of 'resource_name' field
body:
Otherwise this field might end up as numeric types (e.g. integer when server returns xml with `<resource_name>24011</resource_name>` in it) when it should always remain a plain string.
This problem already was fixed in some places with 6db6e7bbd57c07774a1a2773f383c7d54c77c5ef but it still remained in other spots..

Existing seishub tests pass locally (http://tests.obspy.org/67117/; CI can't run them because test server is on our internal network..), should be good to merge.

C:\Miniconda-x64\envs\test\python.exe: Could not load shared library "libmseed_Windows_64bit_py27.pyd".

First bad appveyor run (on Python 2.7.13), dating from 2016-12-19: https://ci.appveyor.com/project/obspy/obspy/build/1.0.3912-master#L25

Upstream bug report for Python: https://bugs.python.org/issue29082

Other projects experiencing the same issue: rg3/youtube-dl#11540 

In principle we could just wait for Python 2.7.14 and tell Windows users to avoid 2.7.13 but it would be better to fix it on our end, I guess.

title: Seedlink client, error in reconnection routine
body:
In file `obspy/clients/seedlink/client/seedlinkconnection.py` at lines 1409 and 1417 concatination of `bytes` and `str` errors occurred.

Steps to reproduce error:
- Create SeedLink with `obspy.clients.seedlink.easyseedlink.create_client`
- Connect to server and get any data
- Shutdown SeedLink server
- Client fall into infinite loop with messages:

```
network timeout (120), reconnecting in 30s
can't concat bytes to str
negotiation with remote SeedLink failed: 'no stations accepted'
```

To fix it change `hex(...)` call in those lines to `hex(...).encode('ascii', 'strict')`.

title: Missing preferred_origin (but it is defined)

labels.name: .core.event
labels.description: issues related to our Catalog/Event functionality

body:
When I retrieve events via the FDSN web client, I occasionally get an event that has a `preferred_origin_id` (and a corresponding entry in `origins`) but `preferred_origin()` returns None.

```python
from obspy.clients import fdsn
client = fdsn.Client('IRIS')

catalog = client.get_events(starttime='2016-12-01', minmagnitude=4)
bad_events = [event for event in catalog if not event.preferred_origin()]
len(bad_events)
```
> 1

```python
bad_event = bad_events[0]
bad_event.preferred_origin_id
```

> smi:service.iris.edu/fdsnws/event/1/query?originid=17807622

```python
bad_event.origins[0].resource_id
```

> smi:service.iris.edu/fdsnws/event/1/query?originid=17807622

But the same event retrieved in a different way appears fine.

```python
catalog = client.get_events(eventid=5199371)
event = catalog[0]
event.preferred_origin()
```

> Origin
    	   resource_id: ResourceIdentifier(id="smi:service.iris.edu/fdsnws/event/1/query?originid=17807622")
    	          time: UTCDateTime(2016, 12, 1, 0, 21, 40, 290000)
    	     longitude: -70.3105
    	      latitude: -28.715
    	         depth: 114950.0
    	 creation_info: CreationInfo(author='us')

Actually, it looks like there is some sort of stateful behavior here, when making repeated requests this behavior oscillates. (The exact values produced here are somewhat unpredictable but the oscillation itself is consistent.)

```python
for _ in range(4):
    catalog = client.get_events(starttime='2016-12-01', minmagnitude=4)
    bad_events = [event for event in catalog if not event.preferred_origin()]
    print "%d of %d bad events" % (len(bad_events), len(catalog))
```

> 768 of 807 bad events
17 of 807 bad events
768 of 807 bad events
17 of 807 bad events

title: Station magnitude residual of zero not read from QuakeML
body:
Using ObsPy 1.02 and Python 3.5 installed via Anaconda on Windows.

Try the following  with [test.zip](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/files/646936/test.zip) unzipped to the working directory:

```python
from obspy import read_events
catalog = read_events('test.xml')
print(catalog.events[0].magnitudes[0].station_magnitude_contributions[2].residual)
catalog.write('test2.xml', 'QuakeML')
```

The problem is that station magnitude residual of 0.0 is read and printed, but not written to test2.xml.
It seems that a residual of 0.0 in the third StationMagnitudeContribution is explicitly ignored on writing; you can change the residual to another value and it will write fine.

I expect a residual of 0.0 to be just as valid as any other value. I would expect a value of None to indicate that the residual is not known or not recorded.

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

Is there a problem with ObsPy?

title: Arrays r_dist and r_ray_num in obspy.taup.seismic_phase.calc_time() are too small
body:
Running get_ray_paths crashes for certain epicentral distances (error message below) in a homegrown TauP model. The problem is related to the hard-coded size of arrays r_dist and r_ray_num in obspy.taup.seismic_phase.calc_time(), which is fixed to 10 arrivals per phase:

 https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/master/obspy/taup/seismic_phase.py#L1009-L1015

Setting the size to something larger than e.g. 20 resolves the problem.

Cheers,

Bernhard

ar = mt.get_ray_paths(172.8000,46.762440693494824,["SS"])

title: NEIC client producing problematic data?
body:
One of my colleagues is getting some problematic data when we request from the neic client.  We weren't sure if this was something on our end or something in obspy.  The following code:

```
#!/usr/bin/env python

from obspy.clients.neic import Client
from obspy.core import UTCDateTime


client = Client()
day = UTCDateTime('2016255')
st = client.get_waveforms('NE' , 'BRYW' , '00' , 'HH2' , day , day + 24*60*60)
```

Results in an internal mseed warning:

```

python check.py 
/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/obspy-1.0.2-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/obspy/io/mseed/core.py:384: InternalMSEEDReadingWarning: readMSEEDBuffer(): Unknown error '121' in record starting at offset 9310720. The rest of the file will not be read.
  warnings.warn(*_i)
```

When we request it through a CWBQuery we don't get an error. In the following sense:
`
java -jar /APPS/bin/CWBQuery.jar -s "NEBRYW HH200" -b "2016/09/11 00:00:00" -d 86400 -t ms`

gives us a miniseed file and it reads correctly:

```
from obspy.core import read
>>> st = read('NEBRYW_HH200.ms')
>>> print(st)
1 Trace(s) in Stream:
NE.BRYW.00.HH2 | 2016-09-11T00:00:00.005000Z - 2016-09-11T23:59:59.995000Z | 100.0 Hz, 8640000 samples
>>> exit()

```

Can anyone confirm if this is an obspy issue (or an issue with something we are doing)?    

Thanks for your help,
Adam

title: read with headonly=True may shift trace starttime for zero data offset records
body:
So apparently the QC module found a gap in a fully continuous trace. Look closely at the start & endtime of the `11771` sample trace when reading in files with and without headonly.

```
print(st.__str__(extended=True))

NL.VKB..BHZ | 2015-05-18T13:21:15.069538Z - 2015-05-18T14:43:39.919538Z | 40.0 Hz, 197795
NL.VKB..BHZ | 2015-05-18T14:43:39.919500Z - 2015-05-18T14:43:39.919500Z | 40.0 Hz, 0
NL.VKB..BHZ | 2015-05-18T14:43:39.944538Z - 2015-05-18T14:48:34.194538Z | 40.0 Hz, 11771
NL.VKB..BHZ | 2015-05-18T14:48:35.119500Z - 2015-05-18T14:48:35.119500Z | 40.0 Hz, 0
```

Setting read headonly=True (used for gap calculation in QC).

```
print(st.__str__(extended=True))

NL.VKB..BHZ | 2015-05-18T13:21:15.069538Z - 2015-05-18T14:43:39.919538Z | 40.0 Hz, 197795
NL.VKB..BHZ | 2015-05-18T14:43:39.919500Z - 2015-05-18T14:48:34.169500Z | 40.0 Hz, 11771
NL.VKB..BHZ | 2015-05-18T14:48:35.119500Z - 2015-05-18T14:48:35.119500Z | 40.0 Hz, 0
```

The first 0 sample trace disappears and the 11771 sample trace assimilates its start time, meaning we are introducing a gap. All other traces in the file remain identical.

Technically related to Mseed zero dataoffset: https://github.com/obspy/obspy/pull/1509 (despite that before this pull we could not even read this file). Any first thoughts on what may cause this spooky behaviour?

File used for demonstration:
ftp://www.orfeus-eu.org/continuous/2015/138/VKB.BHZ.NL.2015.138

title: SAC: writing to disk a new Trace object ignores custom header fields, if an arrival time is set
body:
Example:

``` python
import numpy as np
from obspy import Trace, read

tr = Trace(np.zeros(1000))
tr.stats.delta = 0.01
tr.stats.station = 'XXX'
tr.stats.sac = {}
tr.stats.sac['stla'] = 10.
tr.stats.sac['stlo'] = -5.
tr.stats.sac['a'] = 12.34
tr.write('test.sac', format='SAC')

tr2 = read('test.sac')[0]
for k, v in sorted(tr2.stats.sac.items()):
    print('{}: {}'.format(k, v))
```

gives the following output:

```
b: 0.0
delta: 0.00999999977648
depmax: 0.0
depmen: 0.0
depmin: 0.0
e: 9.98999977112
iftype: 1
iztype: 9
kstnm: XXX
lcalda: 0
leven: 1
lovrok: 1
lpspol: 1
npts: 1000
nvhdr: 6
nzhour: 0
nzjday: 1
nzmin: 0
nzmsec: 0
nzsec: 0
nzyear: 1970
scale: 1.0
```

i.e., the custom header fields `stla`, `stlo` and `a` are not written to disk.
When removing the line:

``` python
tr.stats.sac['a'] = 12.34
```

the two remaining custom fields are correctly written to disk, so I assume that this line is failing silently.

This bug (regression?) appears on both the current master and the maintenance branch.

title: Fixing issue when writing StationXML with manually set poles and zeroes.

labels.name: .io
labels.description: issues generally related to our read/write plugins

body:
Another last minute fix for 1.0.2!! Very small fix but it solves a nasty problem. Includes a regression test.

This fixes an issue when manually settings poles and zeros in a response object and serializing to StationXML. StationXML requires `numbers` attributes which have to be written.

``` python
# cut down to a single channel.
inv = obspy.read_inventory()
inv.networks = inv[:1]
inv[0].stations = inv[0][:1]
inv[0][0].channels = inv[0][0][:1]

# Manually set the poles and zeros - thus these are cast to our
# custom classes but number are not yet set.
inv[0][0][0].response.response_stages[0].poles = [0 + 1j, 2 + 3j]
inv[0][0][0].response.response_stages[0].zeros = [0 + 1j, 2 + 3j]

inv.write("test.xml", format="stationxml")
```

Output without this PR:

``` xml
              <Zero>
                <Real>0.0</Real>
                <Imaginary>1.0</Imaginary>
              </Zero>
              <Zero>
                <Real>2.0</Real>
                <Imaginary>3.0</Imaginary>
              </Zero>
              <Pole>
                <Real>0.0</Real>
                <Imaginary>1.0</Imaginary>
              </Pole>
              <Pole>
                <Real>2.0</Real>
                <Imaginary>3.0</Imaginary>
              </Pole>
```

Output with this PR:

``` xml
              <Zero number="0">
                <Real>0.0</Real>
                <Imaginary>1.0</Imaginary>
              </Zero>
              <Zero number="1">
                <Real>2.0</Real>
                <Imaginary>3.0</Imaginary>
              </Zero>
              <Pole number="0">
                <Real>0.0</Real>
                <Imaginary>1.0</Imaginary>
              </Pole>
              <Pole number="1">
                <Real>2.0</Real>
                <Imaginary>3.0</Imaginary>
              </Pole>
```

title: read nlloc hypocenter-phase file with more than one event in it
body:
ObsPy version 1.0.1
Python version 3.4.4
Platform: OSX
Installed using Anaconda

Your NonLinLoc "catalog reader" only appears to return the last event in the NLLoc .hyp file.  I looked at the source code (in ~/anaconda/pkgs/obspy-1.0.1-py34_0/lib/python3.4/site-packages/obspy/io/nlloc/core.py) and it appears that this is deliberate (the code updates indices_hyp[0] and indices_hyp[1] until the end of the file rather then reading them once encountered).

Wayne Crawford

title: Fixes for beachball patch: semi-transparent double-couple beachball (i.e. alpha!=1); non-DC beachball with nofill=True
body:
This fixes two bugs when plotting beachball patches.

1) Beachball patches are currently plotted by a simple full circle filled with the tension area color (edit: actually this is not true for some strike/dip/rake combinations, added another example focal mechanism), overlain by complex closed path(s) filled with the pressure area color. This leads to the problem that when setting `alpha` to something less than 1, i.e. a semi-transparent beachball patch, that the pressure areas become a blend of both the pressure color as well as the underlying tension color.
For DC beachballs the existing algorithm allows to simply work around this bug by doing the complex path plotting twice, once for tension and once for pressure area and thus getting rid of the full circle in the background. Unfortunately, the non-DC plotting code always selects the easier to draw paths and can not simply be tricked into drawing the second set of paths.

While this PR will lead to inconsistency in the coloring between DC and non-DC semi-transparent patches, I still think it's better to fix at least that low-hanging-fruit-part of the bug. (Also considering that presumably many studies will _either_ have strike/dip/rake solutions _or_ full moment tensors, depending on the used methodology)

N.b.: The mopad plotting routines also have a similar color blending issue (although the underlying patch seems to not always be a full circle)

**Before:** (color blend bug in both DC and non-DC plots)
![alpha_before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1842780/16487048/bc80a74a-3ec8-11e6-8f43-5a25d5c718ee.png)

**After:** (color blend bug fixed in DC plots, still present in non-DC plots)
![alpha_after](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1842780/16487050/bf1d61fa-3ec8-11e6-9f1b-95e96d9faffb.png)

2) There was a bug in plotting non-DC beachballs without fill colors. The DC plotting ends up in always two patches, until now one full circle and the pressure area path and using only the second patch for the outline is enough (it also includes the circle outline).
On the other hand, the non-DC plotting ends up with one full circle patch and 0-x paths for the simpler to draw areas whether pressure or tension. So far, for non-DC patches only the first complex paths was used and all eventual additional patches disregarded. There was a "need to check" comment in there that was never looked at again, stumbled over it while working on the first bug..

**Before:**
![nofill_before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1842780/16487057/c54c7fca-3ec8-11e6-9246-6a98b338fca3.png)

**After:**
![nofill_after](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1842780/16487059/c8a84c6c-3ec8-11e6-9761-3061e8c02d54.png)

Code used to generate the images:

``` python
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from obspy.imaging.beachball import beach

colors = ['g', 'r']
alpha = 0.4
width = 200

for nofill in (False, True):
    fig = plt.figure(figsize=(9, 9))
    ax = fig.add_subplot(111)
    yoffset = 0

    for focmec_ in ((40, 80, 10), [274, 13, 55], [0.91, -0.89, -0.02, 1.78, -1.55, 0.47]):
        b = beach(focmec_, xy=(50, yoffset), width=width, axes=ax, zorder=10,
                  alpha=alpha, facecolor=colors[0], bgcolor=colors[1],
                  nofill=nofill)
        ax.add_collection(b)
        b = beach(focmec_, xy=(220, yoffset), width=width, axes=ax, zorder=10,
                  alpha=alpha, facecolor=colors[0], bgcolor="w", nofill=nofill)
        ax.add_collection(b)
        yoffset += 250

    ax.set_xlim(-120, 350)
    ax.set_ylim(-120, 600)
    ax.text(-100, 0, "plot_dc()")
    ax.text(-100, 250, "plot_dc()")
    ax.text(-100, 500, "plot_mt()")
    ax.text(0, 120, "/".join(colors))
    ax.text(220, 120, "/".join((colors[0], "w")))

    fig.tight_layout()

plt.draw()
plt.show()
```

title: SLIST/TSPAIR: fix writing files with floating point sampling rates + don't set 'stats.mseed.dataquality' with a blank

labels.name: .io
labels.description: issues generally related to our read/write plugins

body:
Writing to SLIST and TSPAIR so far wrote sampling rate formatted as an integer into file headers, leading to..
- raised exceptions for <1 Hz sampling rates, and far worse..
- plain wrong output files >1 Hz non-integer sampling rates

Although [format definition](http://ds.iris.edu/ds/nodes/dmc/data/formats/simple-ascii/) only shows examples with integer sampling rates and doesn't speak about floating point sampling rates, when [looking at served data](service.iris.edu/irisws/timeseries/1/query?net=IU&sta=ANMO&loc=00&cha=VHZ&starttime=2005-01-01T00:00:00&endtime=2005-01-01T00:01:00&output=ascii), the sampling rate is just written as a float with "`.`":

```
TIMESERIES IU_ANMO_00_VHZ_M, 6 samples, 0.1 sps, 2005-01-01T00:00:07.986000, SLIST, INTEGER, COUNTS
-3643
-3658
-3636
-3618
-3628
-3668
```

Safest thing it to just leave it to Python to format the sampling rate as a string. This might lead to scientific notation in output for very crazy sampling rates but that shouldn't be a problem (at least not for us.. ;-).

Although probably not a lot of people use these formats, this is a **very** bad bug  and I think warrants a 1.0.2 release.

title: MiniSEED files is also (in the header) a valid tarfile....

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

body:
Curious issue from the mailing list:

http://lists.swapbytes.de/archives/obspy-users/2016-June/002072.html

The problem is that our uncompress_file decorator thinks this is a tarfile and even manages to unpack one 0 byte file. Even the tar utility thinks its a (corrupt) tarfile.

This PR fixes the issue by just not appending empty untarred files to the list of unpacked objects. Thus nothing will be unpacked and ObsPy thinks this is not a tarfile and the rest of the format detection routines proceeds normally.

Duplicate of #1435 but this time with the correct base branch.

title: Future's filter() method acts as imposter for obspy.signal.filter
body:
Small bug and **only on Python 2.7**:

In `obspy/signal/__init__.py`, the line

``` python
from future.builtins import *
```

imports a `filter()` method (just an alias to `itertools.ifilter`) - people just importing `obspy.signal` will thus find `obspy.signal.filter` which is not the expected filter method.

``` python
import obspy.signal
obspy.signal.filter.lowpass(...)
```

thus results in 

```
type object 'itertools.ifilter' has no attribute ‘lowpass’. 
```

There are of course ways around this but it is still annoying and might confuse users so we should fix it.

title: Possible memory leak in remove_response() (numpy FFT cache growing)

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

body:
I'm trying to use ObsPy to remove the instrument response from a whole year of data of a station, so I wrote a python script that loops over the miniseed files and apply the relevant functions. What I found out is that after a while the script gets killed by the kernel's out of memory killer. Indeed the memory it uses grows indefinitely during the iterations.

I wrote a minimal example that is able to reproduce this issue, you'll be able to see the memory growing using `top` or similar tools. 

``` python
#!/usr/bin/python

from __future__ import print_function
import sys

import obspy
import obspy.clients.fdsn

for i in range(1,365):

    t = obspy.UTCDateTime(year=2014, julday=i)

    client = obspy.clients.fdsn.Client('IPGP')
    st = client.get_waveforms(network="G", station="CCD", location="00", channel="BHZ", starttime=t, endtime=(t + 86400), attach_response=True)

    tr = st[0]

    tr.remove_response()

    print('.', end="")
    sys.stdout.flush()
```

I'm using python-obspy 1.0.1 from the `deb.obspy.org` Debian repository on an up-to-date Debian "sid" system:

```
~ $ uname -a
Linux mandragola 4.5.0-2-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 4.5.4-1 (2016-05-16) x86_64 GNU/Linux
~ $ python --version

title: obspy.taup - Missing core phases in the absence of inner core
body:
Hi,

I think there is a bug in the TauP package (also might go with #1200):
[I am using obspy version 1.0.1 installed with conda 4.0.6 under python 2.7.11]

I just tested obspy.taup package using a structure file representing Mars w/wo an inner core. The core phases (e.g. PKP, SKS etc) are not populated when there is no inner core. Of course there will be no **I/i** phases, but the **K** phases should exist. When I implement a small inner core (with 0.5 km radius) in the model file, the travel times for the related phases are computed. 

Here is an example output from my script for a source at distance=100 degrees and depth=50 km for three phases; SS, SKKS, SKS [this one is in shadow zone according to the model].

```
WITH INNER CORE:
        SS phase arrival at 1377.796 seconds [JavaTauP=1377.80]
        SKKS phase arrival at 1850.966 seconds [JavaTauP=1850.97]

NO INNER CORE:
        SS phase arrival at 1377.796 seconds
```

This is also an issue for the recent pre-release Java version of 2.3.0. I haven't tested it with the latest official release as I just realized there is one. 

And here are the nd files I used for testing:
[ModelDW-BFGeoth.noInnerCore.nd.txt](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/files/280682/ModelDW-BFGeoth.noInnerCore.nd.txt)
[ModelDW-BFGeoth.nd.txt](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/files/280684/ModelDW-BFGeoth.nd.txt)

 Edit: Stefanie Hempel realized this problem initially with earlier Java versions and she was working on solving this. Maybe she found one.

title: Handling of invalid times when parsing SEED volumes (xseed).

milestone.description: Bug fix maintenance release for 1.4.0

body:
I came across a SEED dataless file which had time set to `24:00:00.0000` in epoch time spans. Even if to some extent it might make sense to indicate the the time span ends with that day, according to the SEED Manual this is not really standard compliant. 

Nonetheless, some programs seems not to enforce this or are resilient, e.g. PDCC and some seiscomp tools. What adds a bit to the confusion and makes it difficult to understand the issue is that Obspy in such a case just silently ignores the value. So if the time is supposed to close an epoch, the parse representation is interpreted as an open ended epoch.

Therefore, I would propose that the behavior wrt parsing invalid datetime value is somewhat modified. I see the following possibilities:
- generate a warning or even an error so that it becomes obvious that the file is not fully compliant;
- accept some invalid values;
- accept some invalid values and generate a warning;

No clear idea what is the best, therefore I start this with as issue. I can provide an PR, once this is discussed and settled.
## 
- ObsPy version, Python version and Platform (Windows, OSX, Linux ...)

Version 1.0.1, Python 3.4.4, OSX/Macports
- How did you install ObsPy and Python (pip, anaconda, from source ...)

Macports
- If possible please supply a [Short, Self Contained, Correct, Example](http://sscce.org/) that demonstrates the issue i.e a small piece of code which reproduces the issue and can be run with out any other (or as few as possible) external dependencies.

Will provide an example dataless if this is relant
- If this is a regression (Used to work in an earlier version of ObsPy), please note where it used to work.

Not investigated

title: SAC file truncated to zero on write if an invalid header field is set

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

body:
Here's a test code:

``` python
from obspy import read

tr = read('trace.sac')[0]
tr.stats.sac.AAA = 10.
tr.write('trace.sac', format='SAC')
```

which gives:

```
ValueError: Unrecognized header name: AAA.
```

And truncates to zero `trace.sac`.

I think that setting an invalid header field should be tested in order to prevent future regressions.

title: mseed recordanalyzer: always displays blockette information of first record
body:
Obspy version 1.0.1-1~wheezy, Debian Wheezy, installed from obspy .deb repository

The file demo.mseed in attachment contains 2 miniseed records of 512 bytes. First one has bloquette 1001 with timing quality set to 10 and second one has bloquette 1001 with timing quality set to  20.

Using recordanalyzer.py to display the timing quality of both records will always show "Timing quality: 10".

The bug is in function  `def _get_blockettes(self)`  where a seek is done from the beginning of the file, but the seek displacement you pass is a value which is the offset of the bloquette relative to the position of the analyzed record. In the seek displacement you forgot to take into account the position of the record with respect to the beginning of the file. Patch is attached.

[demo.mseed.zip](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/files/238686/demo.mseed.zip)
[recordanalyzer_patch.txt](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/files/238687/recordanalyzer_patch.txt)

body:
Reading some QuakeML files multiple times results in a warning getting issued that is supposed to only show up when objects with same ResourceIdentifier string but different content get serialized:

``` python
from StringIO import StringIO
from obspy import read_events
from obspy.core.event import ResourceIdentifier

sio = StringIO("""<?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
<q:quakeml xmlns:q="http://quakeml.org/xmlns/quakeml/1.2"
           xmlns="http://quakeml.org/xmlns/bed/1.2">
  <eventParameters publicID="smi:local/catalog">
    <event publicID="smi:local/event">
      <origin publicID="smi:local/origin">
        <time>
          <value>1970-01-01T00:00:00.000000Z</value>
        </time>
        <latitude>
          <value>0.0</value>
        </latitude>
        <longitude>
          <value>0.0</value>
        </longitude>
        <depth>
          <value>0.0</value>
        </depth>
        <arrival publicID="smi:local/arrival">
          <pickID>smi:local/pick</pickID>
          <phase>P</phase>
        </arrival>
      </origin>
    </event>
  </eventParameters>
</q:quakeml>
""")

cat1 = read_events(sio)
cat2 = read_events(sio)
```

```
/home/megies/git/obspy/obspy/core/event/base.pyc:324: UserWarning: The resource identifier 'smi:local/origin' already exists and points to another object: 'Origin(resource_id=ResourceIdentifier(id="smi:local/origin"), time=UTCDateTime(1970, 1, 1, 0, 0), longitude=0.0, latitude=0.0, depth=0.0)'.It will now point to the object referred to by the new resource identifier.
  Will return None if no object could be found.
```

The warning does not show up when removing the `Arrival` tag from the example QuakeML string.

title: Sporadic fail in wrapped evalresp C routines in combination with QT4AGG matplotlib backend

labels.name: .core

body:
We've come across a strange and disturbing test fail today. The failure happens inside `signal.invsim.evalresp` and is triggered by executing `core/tests/test_trace.py` in test routine `test_remove_response()`.

So far this has only occurred on @fstettner's computer (Ubuntu Linux 14.04, 64bit, Python 3 Anaconda, ObsPy 1.0.1 -- could also reproduce the issue on that same computer on a fresh Anaconda 2), and I'm failing to reproduce the issue on my computer (although I'm on Linux 64bit as well and also tried a fresh Anaconda install).

What makes it even more ugly is that **execution order of tests plays a role** (`py.test test_trace.py -k test_remove_response` runs OK, while `py.test test_trace.py` fails). We confirmed this fact by using `pytest-random` pytest plugin (`pip install pytest-random`) to shuffle order of execution of all tests in `test_trace.py` (doing 100 random runs produced 22 fails):

title: SAC output ignores sampling rate from Trace metadata

title: FDSN Client not allowing valid local computer URLs

title: Out of Bounds Error assigning station latitude to SAC Header
body:
In obspy v1.0.0, SACTrace  can be used to initialize the sac header dictionary to get around some changes in the SAC io modules resulting in another bug (see [https://github.com/obspy/obspy/issues/1285] for details).

After reading a miniseed file to a stream or downloading data to a stream via a client, the trace is converted via SACTrace:
`trsac = obspy.io.sac.sactrace.SACTrace.from_obspy_trace(tr)`

The station latitude can now be assigned:
`trsac.stla = -35.0`
However, this produces the following error:
`Latitude of Point 1 out of bounds! (-90 <= lat1 <=90)`

The value is clearly in the appropriate range of values. Furthermore, in ipython, querying the value shows it was actually applied:
`print trsac.stla`
`-35.0`
It appears that the value is being assigned, but following the assignment of this single value, gps2_distazimuth in obspy.geodetics is being called, which is where the error message is originating.

This is on a computer running Ubuntu 14.04 x86_64 with python2.7 and obspy v1.0.0 installed via the package manager.
Note that no error is produced running the same operation on the same data on a 64bit Windows 10 Laptop running python3.4 and obspy v1.0.0.

labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

milestone.description: Bug fix maintenance release for 1.3.0 (if needed)

body:
I just came across behavior regarding attach_response() which I would consider at least unexpected and propose this should be changes. 

When using `Stream.attach_response()` with an `Inventory` which has only level `channel`, I got no skipped traces, even if even if the `Inventory` has no response details. It just will pass, but obviously at a later stage removal of responses with `remove_response()` would fail:

ObsPyException: Can not use evalresp on response with no response stages.

Looking into the details it is probably `Trace.attach_response()`, which should detect the missing response information and raise. Instead it just creates a empty `response` attribute in `Stats`, for example:
