title: getPAZ behavior with multiple blockette 53s
body:
Hello

I believe there might be an issue with the getPAZ routine, when a response has multiple blockette 53 stages.  An example of this would be: http://service.iris.edu/irisws/resp/1/query?net=II&sta=PFO&loc=00&cha=LHZ&starttime=2015-10-08T16:00:00&endtime=2599-12-31T23:59:59

When I run the following script 

``` python
#!/usr/bin/env python

from obspy.xseed import Parser
from obspy.core import UTCDateTime

parser = Parser('/APPS/metadata/SEED/II.dataless')
paz = parser.getPAZ('II.PFO.00.LHZ', UTCDateTime('2016-001T00:00:00.0'))

print(paz)
```

I get the following output:

```
[aringler@igskgacgvmres01 ~]$ python checkII.py 
/usr/lib64/python2.6/site-packages/obspy/xseed/parser.py:1071: UserWarning: More than one Abbreviation Dictionary Control Headers found!
  warnings.warn(msg, UserWarning)
{u'sensitivity': 5641740000.0, u'digitizer_gain': 1.0,
 u'seismometer_gain': 3602.4000000000001, u'zeros': [],
 u'gain': 1.0, u'poles': []}
[aringler@igskgacgvmres01 ~]$ 
```

However, I believe the output should be:

```
{u'sensitivity': 5641740000.0, u'digitizer_gain': 1.0,
 u'seismometer_gain': 3602.4000000000001, u'zeros': [0j, 0j, (-493.48022005446791+0j), (-0.95821225640944263+0j), (-0.95821225640944263+0j)],
 u'gain': 6.2831853071795862, u'poles': [(-0.076039380147752855+0.0718179529533189j), (-0.076039380147752855-0.0718179529533189j), (-0.90191998074738944+0.36210907414497578j), (-0.90191998074738944-0.36210907414497578j), (-248.21699762981297+483.10923974980324j), (-248.21699762981297-483.10923974980324j)]}
[aringler@igskgacgvmres01 ~]$ 
```

I think the declaration of the poles and zeros (lines 581 and 573 of parser.py) needs to be moved up so that they aren't reset as empty lists every time an additional blockette 53 or 60 is found.

If this is in fact an issue, then I would be happy to correct it and make a pull request.  If I am totally missing something than I apologize for confusing people!

Best,
Adam

title: problems with urlencode for ISC FDSN service
body:
Due to how `urllib.parse.urlencode` constructs the requested URL (specifically, converting `:` to `%3A`) we have a problem requesting from ISC FDSN service:

Works: http://isc-mirror.iris.washington.edu/fdsnws/event/1/query?starttime=2001-06-23T20:31:00&endtime=2001-06-23T20:37:00

Doesn't work: http://isc-mirror.iris.washington.edu/fdsnws/event/1/query?starttime=2001-06-23T20%3A31%3A00&endtime=2001-06-23T20%3A37%3A00

Which results in problems for us:

``` python
from obspy import UTCDateTime
from obspy.fdsn import Client
client = Client("ISC")
# raises an Exception, because we get an unexpected info page
client.get_events(starttime=UTCDateTime("2001-06-23T20:31:00"),
                  endtime=UTCDateTime("2001-06-23T20:37:00"))
```

I guess this is a problem in the upstream server implementation?

title: Variable TauP Radius
body:
This PR enables `obspy.taup` to parse planets with varying radius. I also did some generic cleanup. Tests still pass.

Planet radii and the depth of various discontinuities used to be hard coded in various places. It is now decided during model parsing what the radius of the planet is and where the discontinuities are.

To some extent it can now also parse mars model which have a liquid core which does not work with the current master. There are still some issues with it but I suspect they are largely due to the fact that we currently did not consider that some discontinuities do not exists - mars has no inner core and thus no IOCB for example. So there are still a couple of things to do.
1. For normal tvel files we should check if the radius is Earth's radius and if not raise an error - that file has no named discontinuities so Earth's discontinuities have to be assumed.
2. nd files have named discontinuities so that should be fine. It currently cannot parse files without an IOCB.
3. We should attempt to have optional discontinuities in the code. How does the Java version deal with this?

A couple of test files if someone wants to play around with it:
- https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/3866312/mars.tvel  (Can be parsed an something can be calculated but the discontinuities are wrong in the TauP model)
- https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/3866312/anderson_mars.nd  (Cannot yet be parsed)

Please don't merge yet - I have to rewrite the history as I accidentally committed the `.npz` files a couple of times...

title: obspy.taup.TauPyModel.get_travel_times() throws an exception for shallow depths
body:
Using depths deeper than 0.0 km and shallower than 1.25 km with iasp91 model result in 

AttributeError: 'TauModel' object has no attribute 'ray_param'

Equivalent input values in java taup results in valid numbers.

```
import obspy.taup
model = obspy.taup.TauPyModel(model='iasp91')
arrivals = model.model.get_travel_times(distance_in_degree=0.9,source_depth_in_km=0.1)
```

reproduces the exception.  Changing the value of source_depth_in_km to 0.0, or 1.25 results the expected behavior.

title: Trace.write generates invalid SAC files under certain conditions

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

body:
This code used to work with ObsPy 0.10.2, but does not work anymore with the new implementation of `obspy.io.sac`:

``` python
import numpy as np
from obspy import Trace
from obspy.core import AttribDict

tr = Trace(np.arange(100))
tr.stats.sac = AttribDict()
tr.stats.sac.stla = 1.
tr.stats.sac.stlo = 2.
tr.write('test.sac', format='SAC')
```

The file produced is invalid sac, since some fundamental header field, like `nvhdr` is not set.

The reason for that is that [`obspy_to_sac_header()`](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/master/obspy/io/sac/util.py#L265) detects an existing header and does not set those basic header fields.

I think that the existence of fields `iztype`, `nvhdr`, `leven`, `lovrok`, `iftype` should always be checked and those fields should be set to default values on writing, if they do not exist.

Now, suppose that one sets those fields by hand: there is another problem with start time, which is not taken into account, for the same reason that an existing header is detected.

The following code produces a valid sac file, but with the date-time header fields set to undef. 

``` python
import numpy as np
from obspy import Trace, UTCDateTime
from obspy.core import AttribDict

tr = Trace(np.arange(100))
tr.stats.starttime = UTCDateTime()
tr.stats.sac = AttribDict()
tr.stats.sac['iztype'] = 9
tr.stats.sac['nvhdr'] = 6
tr.stats.sac['leven'] = 1
tr.stats.sac['lovrok'] = 1
tr.stats.sac['iftype'] = 1
tr.stats.sac.stla = 1.
tr.stats.sac.stlo = 2.
tr.write('test.sac', format='SAC')
```

Again, I think that we should check on write if the header date-time fields are unset and, in case, set them according to `tr.stats.starttime`.

@jkmacc-LANL What do you think?

title: Minor fixes to Stream.getGaps()/Stream.printGaps()

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

body:
As reported by @ltrani in #1141, one-sample overlaps are currently specified as `delta = 0.0`, and one-sample gaps are specified as `delta = 2 * sampling_interval`.

To reproduce:

``` python
from obspy import read, Stream
tr = read()[0]
tr_ = tr.copy()
tr.data = tr.data[:1500]
tr_.data = tr_.data[1499:]
tr_.stats.starttime += 14.99
st_one_sample_overlap = Stream([tr.copy(), tr_.copy()])
tr_.data = tr_.data[2:]
tr_.stats.starttime += 0.02
st_one_sample_gap = Stream([tr.copy(), tr_.copy()])
st_one_sample_overlap.printGaps()
st_one_sample_gap.printGaps()
```

```
Source            Last Sample                 Next Sample                 Delta           Samples 
BW.RJOB..EHZ      2009-08-24T00:20:17.990000Z 2009-08-24T00:20:17.990000Z 0.000000        1       
Total: 0 gap(s) and 1 overlap(s)
Source            Last Sample                 Next Sample                 Delta           Samples 
BW.RJOB..EHZ      2009-08-24T00:20:17.990000Z 2009-08-24T00:20:18.010000Z 0.020000        1       
Total: 1 gap(s) and 0 overlap(s)
```

This should be fixed to compute the delta time across two traces `A` and `B` as `starttime_B - (endtime_A + sampling_interval_A)`, which then gives:

```
Source            Last Sample                 Next Sample                 Delta           Samples 
BW.RJOB..EHZ      2009-08-24T00:20:18.000000Z 2009-08-24T00:20:17.990000Z -0.010000       1       
Total: 0 gap(s) and 1 overlap(s)
Source            Last Sample                 Next Sample                 Delta           Samples 
BW.RJOB..EHZ      2009-08-24T00:20:18.000000Z 2009-08-24T00:20:18.010000Z 0.010000        1       
Total: 1 gap(s) and 0 overlap(s)
```

Furthermore, overlaps specified in units of samples should be negative integers:

```
Source            Last Sample                 Next Sample                 Delta           Samples 
BW.RJOB..EHZ      2009-08-24T00:20:17.990000Z 2009-08-24T00:20:17.990000Z -0.010000       -1      
Total: 0 gap(s) and 1 overlap(s)
Source            Last Sample                 Next Sample                 Delta           Samples 
BW.RJOB..EHZ      2009-08-24T00:20:17.990000Z 2009-08-24T00:20:18.010000Z 0.010000        1       
Total: 1 gap(s) and 0 overlap(s)
```

title: Minor bug in triggering: last occurence of characteristic function falling gelow off threshold is missed

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

body:
First discovered by @petrrr, by switching to numpy 1.10. Numpy 1.10 is now showing a warning when a boolean index array gets expanded to match the shape of the array that is being indexed.

See posts on numpy mailing list:
https://mail.scipy.org/pipermail/numpy-discussion/2015-August/073467.html

```
obspy/signal/tests/test_trigger.py /home/megies/git/obspy/obspy/signal/trigger.py:349: VisibleDeprecationWarning: boolean index did not match indexed array along dimension 0; dimension is 3395 but corresponding boolean dimension is 3394
  of.extend(ind2[np.diff(ind2) > 1].tolist())
```

The `np.diff()` can't make use of the last item, so the last time the trigger's characteristic function is falling below the off-threshold was not used. We have to add that last item by hand.

I'm not sure if this glitch actually had a negative impact right now, though. My feeling is that this only has an influence in extreme edge cases, namely when the last time the characteristic function falls below the off-threshold is actually closely preceeded by an exceedance of the on-threshold. Even then, with `max_len_delete=False` (default) my guess is that the length of that trigger might be wrong, and that only with `max_len_delete=True` this could actually lead to a missed trigger.. but the code is not easy to read..

(btw.. numpy is also working around `DeprecationWarning`s not shown by default on Python nowadays.. ;-))

title: fix some bugs in obspy-scan

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

body:
- sorting or restricting data (to given start/end time) was only
  changing the data list but not the sampling rate list, potentially
  leading to exceptions and/or misinterpreted data regarding gaps / gap
  length (in my case to an empty plot when `--start-time` was
  specified)
- in case of invalid sampling_rates the length of data and sampling
  rate lists could have diverged, potentially leading to exceptions
  and/or misinterpreted data regarding gaps / gap length
- `--end-time` command line option was only usable in combination with
  `--start-time` due to a misformed `if` clause

Fix + regression test for a bug in the Lanczos interpolation routine.

Really bad bug that resulted in a potentially quite significant time shift if the original sampling rate is not 1 Hz and the new and old start times are not identical. Most tests work with 1 Hz as its simple to reason about it so this bug was not caught...

title: Bug in `Trace.remove_response(..., water_level=None)`

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

body:
When water level was set to `None` (i.e. no water level used, solely relying on `pre_filt`) the instrument response spectrum was never inverted but multiplied in frequency domain anyway, thus resulting in a convolution rather a deconvolution, resulting in completely unexpected and unusable results.
Before the fix this was just simply circumvented by specifying a high water_level value (e.g. `water_level=600`) which effectively means no water level at all.

Thanks to @cja12 for letting me know!

Here is a notebook to visualize the issue (esp. see bug last three boxes):
https://gist.github.com/megies/73af368d7f625fb13b0d

``` python
>>> from obspy import UTCDateTime

2011-01-25T15:32:12.259

2011-01-25T15:32:12.260
```

After:

``` python
>>> from obspy import UTCDateTime
```


title: setup.py: add setuptools dependency

labels.name: packaging
labels.description: issue related to our packaging efforts (e.g. conda, Debian, ...)

body:
There are several import from the `pkg_resources` module provided by the `setuptools` packages within the code. 

```
petr% grep pkg_ -r * |grep import
grep: misc/docs/source/tutorial/ObsPyTutorial.pdf: No such file or directory
misc/installer/salt-formula/obspy/dependencies.sls:{% from "obspy/map.jinja" import pkg_deps with context %}
obspy/core/event.py:from pkg_resources import load_entry_point
obspy/core/stream.py:from pkg_resources import load_entry_point
obspy/core/tests/test_waveform_plugins.py:from pkg_resources import load_entry_point
obspy/core/util/base.py:from pkg_resources import iter_entry_points, load_entry_point
obspy/station/inventory.py:from pkg_resources import load_entry_point
setup.py:        from pkg_resources import EntryPoint
```

Therefore adding `setuptools` as explicit requirement, its a "library dependency". 

However, given the fact that `setuptools` has to be installed anyway, we might want it to become an normal install time dependency and get ride of the try/except constructs in the `setup.py` file. Any opinions on this?

body:
I am failing to understand the result of rotate2ZNE and I think the problem is in _dip_azimuth2ZSE_base_vector. If I build the matrix, I observe two problems: 

``` .python
#!/usr/bin/env python
import numpy as np
from obspy.signal.rotate import _dip_azimuth2ZSE_base_vector

dip_1, dip_2, dip_3, = 35.3, 35.3, 35.3
azimuth_1, azimuth_2, azimuth_3 = 0., 120., 240.

base_vector_1 = _dip_azimuth2ZSE_base_vector(dip_1, azimuth_1)
base_vector_2 = _dip_azimuth2ZSE_base_vector(dip_2, azimuth_2)
base_vector_3 = _dip_azimuth2ZSE_base_vector(dip_3, azimuth_3)

T = np.matrix([base_vector_1, base_vector_2, base_vector_3]).transpose()
print(T)
[[-0.57785762  0.28892881  0.28892881]
 [-0.81613759  0.4080688   0.4080688 ]
 [ 0.          0.8660254  -0.8660254 ]]

```

according to Wieland, this is what the matrix should look like:

![wieland](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2306288/7860781/4bfae708-054c-11e5-8735-8d2aecef7209.png)

However, for the Z component (first line of T, last line in Wielands notation), the values are not all the same. Secondly, the matrix is not invertible, which it should be because the components are linearly independent;

This is what I would need at the moment, because I want to compute UVW given NEZ.

Also, the tests seem to cover only very specific examples (orthogonal bases).

labels.name: .core.inventory
labels.description: issues related to our Inventory functionality

milestone.description: Bugs to be addressed in the "releases" branch.

body: According to the [FDSN xml schema (the extension for data availability)](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/master/obspy/io/stationxml/data/fdsn-station%2Bavailability-1.0.xsd) data availability is defined for all of network/station/channel and not only for channel. It thus should be moved to the parent class `BaseNode`.

title: SacIO() fails with python 2.7

milestone.description: Bugs to be addressed in the "releases" branch.

body:
When using python 2.7, the following code fails:

``` python
from obspy.sac import SacIO
with open('test.sac') as fh:
    sac = SacIO(fh)
```

with the following error:

``` python
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for -: 'NoneType' and 'long'
```

This is related to [this line of code](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/releases/obspy/sac/sacio.py#L470), since `file.seek()` does not return anything in python 2.7, and therefore `length` is `None`.

Tests pass on python 2.7 probably because of: 

``` python
from future.builtins import *
```

Following [this answer on Stack Overflow](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2104080/how-to-check-file-size-in-python/19079887#19079887), I suggest (sorry, I have no time to make a PR):

``` python
cur_pos = fh.tell()
fh.seek(0, os.SEEK_END)
size = fh.tell()
fh.seek(cur_pos, os.SEEK_SET)
```

(note also the use of `os.SEEK_END` and `os.SEEK_SET` for better code readability).

title: Seisan waveforms misaligned / wrong by one offset

milestone.description:
The key new features are support for Python 3, a slew of new file formats, and a new TauP implementation.

[Migration Guide from older ObsPy Versions](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/wiki/What%27s-New-in-ObsPy-0.10.0)

body:
Resolves #970. supersedes #969.

Original #969 description:

---

It seems there is a bug when importing SEISAN waveform files. This can be checked when importing the test files in obspy/seisan/tests . Basicaly, the last sample of the data array usually has an unusually high value, resulting in a strange jerk/pulse in the waveform file. Because of this I usually just do

``` python
for el in st:
    el.data = el.data[:-1]
```

to delete the last sample...

I provided two waveform files, one in SEISAN, and another in MSEED which was converted from the SEISAN waveform using SEISAN/wavetool . However, I have tested the test waveforms already provided in the repository obspy/seisan/tests/data and the results is the same, altough the amplitude of the waveforms does obsfuscate this bug sometimes...

title: remove problematic `.__add__()` handling of custom float/complex types

milestone.description:
The key new features are support for Python 3, a slew of new file formats, and a new TauP implementation.

[Migration Guide from older ObsPy Versions](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/wiki/What%27s-New-in-ObsPy-0.10.0)

body:
I think we need to remove those `__add__` methods, they can interfere badly with computations on e.g. latitude values of events/stations...

``` python
from obspy import readEvents, read_inventory
from urllib import urlopen
catalog = readEvents("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/obspy/docs/master/workshops/2014_mess/data/obspy/event_tohoku_mainshock.xml")
inventory = read_inventory(urlopen("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/obspy/docs/master/workshops/2014_mess/data/obspy/station_BFO.xml"), "STATIONXML")
from obspy.core.util.geodetics import gps2DistAzimuth
station = inventory[0][0]
event = catalog[0]
origin = event.origins[0]
print gps2DistAzimuth(origin.latitude, origin.longitude,
                      station.latitude, station.longitude)
```

One of these lines inside the geodetics routine makes problems because the derived values get again initilaized as a Latitude object and fall out of bounds (>180)..

``` python
lat2 = lat2 * 2.0 * math.pi / 360.
```

title: unpurged requests left behind at server
body: People at GFZ just mentioned that we leave behind unpurged requests at server side. In principle we send a `PURGE` at the end of each request operation (e.g. https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/master/obspy/arclink/client.py#L363) but it seems that in some cases a `PURGE` is not sent..

title: Record Section Plot Question/Bug?

labels.name: question
labels.description: Questions asked by users. Please use https://discourse.obspy.org for asking new questions

milestone.description:
The key new features are support for Python 3, a slew of new file formats, and a new TauP implementation.

[Migration Guide from older ObsPy Versions](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/wiki/What%27s-New-in-ObsPy-0.10.0)

body:
From the mailing list (just reformatted a bit): http://lists.swapbytes.de/archives/obspy-users/2014-November/001581.html

Dear All,

Having three issues with stream plot `st.plot(type='section')` in FC20 linux, with obspy0.9.2

``` python
>>> import obspy
>>> print obspy.__version__
0.9.2
```
1. The traces are assumed to have the same start time. (There is no relative shifting between traces, as in `plot(type='normal')`. Easy to handle if known, but If this is a feature, not a bug, it would be good to state this in the docs?
2. scaling/normalization: in `plot(type='normal')` the parameter is `equal_scale`. `equal_scale` works fine, but In `plot(type='section')` the parameter is norm. (Why not use `equal_scale` in section?) But I can't get norm to do anything, despite:

``` python
def __sectNormalizeTraces(self):
        """
        This helper function normalizes the traces
        """
        self._tr_normfac = np.ones(self._tr_num)
        if self.sect_norm_method == 'trace':
            # Normalize against each traces' maximum
            for tr in range(self._tr_num):
                self._tr_normfac[tr] = np.abs(self._tr_data[tr]).max()
        elif self.sect_norm_method == 'stream':
            # Normalize the whole stream
            self._tr_normfac.fill(self._tr_max_count_glob)
        else:
            msg = 'Define a normalisation method. Valid normalisations' +\
                'are \'trace\', \'stream\'. See documentation.'
            raise ValueError(msg)

        self._plot_init = False
```

but given the fact that I don't get msg even if I say: 

``` python
plot(type='section', norm='bla') 
```

makes me think that it is not used at all. I don't understand this because it appears to be called here:

``` python
def plotSection(self, *args, **kwargs):
        """
        Plots multiple waveforms as a record section on a single plot.
        """
        # Initialise data and plot
        self.__sectInitTraces()
         self.__sectInitPlot()
....
```

where:

``` python
def __sectInitPlot(self):
        """
        Function initialises plot all the illustration is done by
        self.plotSection()
        """
        ax = self.fig.gca()
        # Calculate normalizing factor
        self.__sectNormalizeTraces()
        # Calculate scaling factor
        self.__sectScaleTraces()
        # ax.plot() prefered over containers
        for _tr in range(self._tr_num):
            # Scale, normalize and shift traces by offset
            # for plotting
            ax.plot(self._tr_data[_tr] / self._tr_normfac[_tr]
                    * (1. / self._sect_scale)
                    + self._tr_offsets_norm[_tr],
                    self._tr_times[_tr])
        self._sect_plot_init = True
```

Can `'section'` use the same scheme as in`type='normal'`, where `equal_scale` does work?
1. Finally, I don't know why, but in `type='section'`, you need a bandpass of sorts. At least in my example, AND in the one on the gallery `waveform_plotting_tutorial_6`:

without the filter:

``` python
#st.filter('bandpass', freqmin=0.1, freqmax=10)
```

I get the following error when using st.plot(type='section') by running python `waveform_plotting_tutorial_6.py`:

``` python
>>> >>> >>> >>> Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/kasper/Downloads/waveform_plotting_tutorial_6.py", line 32, in <module>
    time_down=True, linewidth=.25, grid_linewidth=.25)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/obspy-0.9.2-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/obspy/core/stream.py", line 1058, in plot
    return waveform.plotWaveform(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/obspy-0.9.2-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/obspy/imaging/waveform.py", line 253, in plotWaveform
    self.plotSection(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/obspy-0.9.2-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/obspy/imaging/waveform.py", line 1114, in plotSection
    self.__sectInitTraces()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/obspy-0.9.2-py2.7-linux-x86_64.egg/obspy/imaging/waveform.py", line 1229, in __sectInitTraces
    self.stream[_tr].data, self.max_npts)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/scipy/signal/signaltools.py", line 1292, in resample
    X = fft(x, axis=axis)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/site-packages/scipy/fftpack/basic.py", line 222, in fft
    raise ValueError("type %s is not supported" % tmp.dtype)
ValueError: type >f4 is not supported
```

Why is there an fft involved in plotting traces in a section? There doesn't seem to be one in `st.plot(type='normal')`, which runs with and without the bandpass filter...

Thanks for your help,
kasper

title: signal.cpxtrace instBwith 'row' referenced before assignment.

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

milestone.description:
The key new features are support for Python 3, a slew of new file formats, and a new TauP implementation.

[Migration Guide from older ObsPy Versions](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/wiki/What%27s-New-in-ObsPy-0.10.0)

body:
It looks like there may have been a copy/paste error within the instBwith `else` clause.  The variable `row` is not defined in the clause.   This has so far been missed by the signal tests.

``` python

In [1]: from obspy.signal import envelope, instBwith

In [2]: from obspy import read

In [3]: tr = read()[0]

In [4]: import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

In [5]: plt.figure(); plt.plot(instBwith(tr.data, 100, (-1.0, 0.0, 1.0)))
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
UnboundLocalError                         Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-5-5f89053a38f3> in <module>()
----> 1 plt.figure(); plt.plot(instBwith(tr.data, 100, (-1.0, 0.0, 1.0)))

/Users/jkmacc/anaconda/lib/python2.7/site-packages/obspy/signal/cpxtrace.pyc in instBwith(data, fs, fk)
    303         # faster alternative to calculate A_win_add
    304         A_win_add = np.hstack(
--> 305             ([row[0]] * (np.size(fk) // 2), row,
    306              [row[np.size(row) - 1]] * (np.size(fk) // 2)))
    307         t = signal.lfilter(fk, 1, A_win_add)

UnboundLocalError: local variable 'row' referenced before assignment
```

A quick patch is to define `row` at the top of the clause:

```
From c72630a9c096bb642cc2c340ba0852ac35e9e937 Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Jonathan MacCarthy <jkmacc@lanl.gov>
Date: Mon, 27 Oct 2014 15:09:33 -0600
Subject: [PATCH] Fixed else loop in signal.instBwith. Looked like a copy/paste
 issue.

---
 obspy/signal/cpxtrace.py | 1 +
 1 file changed, 1 insertion(+)

diff --git a/obspy/signal/cpxtrace.py b/obspy/signal/cpxtrace.py
index 8f88720..4f231b8 100644
--- a/obspy/signal/cpxtrace.py
+++ b/obspy/signal/cpxtrace.py
@@ -299,6 +299,7 @@ def instBwith(data, fs, fk):
         dsigma = dsigma[size(fk) - 1:size(dsigma)]
         return sigma, dsigma
     else:
+        row = x[1]
         sigma = np.zeros(size(x[0]), dtype='float64')
         # faster alternative to calculate A_win_add
         A_win_add = np.hstack(
-- 
1.8.5.2 (Apple Git-48)

```

title: Array Processing date formatting issue and potential bug

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

labels.name: docs
labels.description: issues that only affect the content of documentation pages, docstrings etc

milestone.description:
The key new features are support for Python 3, a slew of new file formats, and a new TauP implementation.

[Migration Guide from older ObsPy Versions](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/wiki/What%27s-New-in-ObsPy-0.10.0)

body:
From the mailinglist: http://lists.swapbytes.de/archives/obspy-users/2014-August/001479.html

> obspy.signal.array_analysis.array_processing returns "Rata Die" date values that are one day earlier than input values. 
> The code snippet 
> http://docs.obspy.org/tutorial/code_snippets/beamforming_fk_analysis.html 
> uses data that starts at 2008-02-17T11:04:58.884998 and ends at 2008-02-17T11:06:01.414998 
> array_processing returns data that starts at 2008-02-16T11:05:15 and ends at 2008-02-16T11:05:43 
> I was expecting the array_process to return data with timestamps inside the raw data period. 
> The attachments include a patch that adds a title and modifies the x-axis so that it shows seconds. 

![agfa_modified](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/800487/4073015/13306176-2e8f-11e4-9ffe-b6dcfbcba083.png)

``` patch
--- beamforming_fk_analysis_1.py    2014-05-05 11:45:33.000000000 +0000
+++ beamforming_fk_analysis_1.py.modified   2014-08-26 14:47:19.507877388 +0000
@@ -1,10 +1,11 @@
 from obspy.core import read, UTCDateTime, AttribDict
 from obspy.signal import cornFreq2Paz
 from obspy.signal.array_analysis import array_processing
+from matplotlib.dates import num2date, SecondLocator, DateFormatter
 import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

 # Load data
-st = read("http://examples.obspy.org/agfa.mseed")
+st = read("agfa.mseed")

 # Set PAZ and coordinates for all 5 channels
 st[0].stats.paz = AttribDict({
@@ -80,15 +81,25 @@
 labels = ['rel.power', 'abs.power', 'baz', 'slow']

 fig = plt.figure()
+out_ym = num2date(out[0, 0]).strftime("%b %Y")
+out_date = num2date(out[0, 0]).strftime("%dth %H:%M:%S")
+st_date = st[0].stats.starttime.datetime.strftime("%dth %H:%M:%S")
+fig.suptitle('AGFA skyscraper blasting in Munich %s (proc/raw: %s/%s)' % (out_ym, out_date, st_date) )
+secM = SecondLocator(bysecond=range(15,45,5))
+secm = SecondLocator()
+secFmt = DateFormatter("%S")
 for i, lab in enumerate(labels):
     ax = fig.add_subplot(4, 1, i + 1)
     ax.scatter(out[:, 0], out[:, i + 1], c=out[:, 1], alpha=0.6,
                edgecolors='none')
     ax.set_ylabel(lab)
+    ax.set_xlabel('seconds')
     ax.set_xlim(out[0, 0], out[-1, 0])
     ax.set_ylim(out[:, i + 1].min(), out[:, i + 1].max())
+    ax.xaxis.set_major_locator(secM)
+    ax.xaxis.set_minor_locator(secm)
+    ax.xaxis.set_major_formatter(secFmt)

-
-fig.autofmt_xdate()
+fig.autofmt_xdate(rotation=0, ha='center')
 fig.subplots_adjust(top=0.95, right=0.95, bottom=0.2, hspace=0)
 plt.show()
```

title: Array analysis matplotlib date conversion bug

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

milestone.description:
The key new features are support for Python 3, a slew of new file formats, and a new TauP implementation.

[Migration Guide from older ObsPy Versions](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/wiki/What%27s-New-in-ObsPy-0.10.0)

body:
From the mailinglist: http://lists.swapbytes.de/archives/obspy-users/2014-August/001478.html

> "Unix Time" to "Rata Die" conversion that takes place here 
> https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/master/obspy/signal/array_analysis.py#L1018 
> is wrong because "Rata Die" epoch starts at 1, not at zero. Add one and it is correct. The comment above that line is wrong. Should be days not hours. 
> 
> Below is a python command line session that hopefully explains why this is wrong 

``` python
>>> from time import time 
>>> from datetime import datetime 
>>> from matplotlib.dates import date2num 
>>> t = time() 
>>> t / (24. * 3600) +719162 - date2num(datetime.fromtimestamp(t)) 
-1.0 
```

title: Trace.resample not setting stats.sampling_rate correctly, if number of points is not an integer multiple of the decimation factor

milestone.description:
The key new features are support for Python 3, a slew of new file formats, and a new TauP implementation.

[Migration Guide from older ObsPy Versions](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/wiki/What%27s-New-in-ObsPy-0.10.0)

body:
Maybe I'm missing something here, but it seems to me as if in Trace.resample(sampling_rate) the Trace.stats.sampling_rate is not properly set in the case that 

``` python
len(tr.data) % (tr.stats.sampling_rate / float(sampling_rate)) != 0.0
```

From the docs of scipy.signal.resample:

> The first sample of the returned vector is the same as the first
> sample of the input vector.  The spacing between samples is changed
> from dx to:
> 
>    dx \* len(x) / num

That is, as far as I understand the docs, the signal x is treated as having fixed length and resampled at num new points. If the condition len(tr.data) % factor != 0.0 is not met, then the actual sampling rate might therefore be different from the desired sampling rate.

However, in Trace.resample (https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/0.9.2/obspy/core/trace.py#L1468),
Trace.stats.sampling_rate is set to with whatever argument the method has been called, as far as I can see.

Thanks for clarification, if I'm wrong. Otherwise, I'd be happy to write a pull request.

title: AttributeError: _ElementInterface instance has no attribute 'nsmap'

milestone.description:
The key new features are support for Python 3, a slew of new file formats, and a new TauP implementation.

[Migration Guide from older ObsPy Versions](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/wiki/What%27s-New-in-ObsPy-0.10.0)

body:
As a followup to #823, the above error is occurring when building on RHEL 6. It appears that the `nsmap` attribute is `lxml`-specific. More than that, it seems that in the version available, it seems that `nsmap` can only be set in the constructor. There is a `_nsmap` attribute, but it's probably supposed to be private.

So in summary, in order to continue using `nsmap`, we'd need to have a hard dependency on `lxml`, plus some kind of patch for the older versions.

title: Problems with unicode dtypes with old numpy versions

milestone.description:
The key new features are support for Python 3, a slew of new file formats, and a new TauP implementation.

[Migration Guide from older ObsPy Versions](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/wiki/What%27s-New-in-ObsPy-0.10.0)

body:
NumPy 1.4 (and potentially 1.5 ?) cannot deal with dtypes specified as unicode strings, .e.g. all of the following do not work:

``` python
np.arange(10, dtype=u"float32")
np.dtype(u"int32")
```

The way the future package is currently use means all string literals are unicode objects even in Python 2.

There is already some discussion on the mailing list:
http://lists.swapbytes.de/archives/obspy-users/2014-June/001395.html

The following is copy from the latest message on the thread

The really bad news for us is that the same issue occurs for all numpy functions accepting a dtype argument, e.g.

``` python
np.arange(10, dtype=u"float32”)
```

also does not work with numpy 1.4 :-(

So we could with either:
1. replace all calls to numpy with dtype settings with 
   
   ``` python
   np.arange(10, dtype=native_string("float32"))
   ```
2. do not use string dtypes, but instead
   
   ``` python
   np.arange(10, dtype=np.float32)
   ```
3. Monkey patch most numpy calls
4. Cease support for NumPy 1.4 with the next release
5. Revert use of the future package in the code base

Number 5 is not really an option as otherwise the future package works remarkably well by now. Neither is 4 as Debian/Ubuntu/RHEL and other long term support linux distros still run that numpy. That leaves 1, 2, and 3.

title: Bug in UTCDateTime

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

milestone.description:
The key new features are support for Python 3, a slew of new file formats, and a new TauP implementation.

[Migration Guide from older ObsPy Versions](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/wiki/What%27s-New-in-ObsPy-0.10.0)

body:
```
Python 2.7.6 (default, Mar 22 2014, 22:59:38) 
[GCC 4.8.2] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from obspy.core import UTCDateTime
>>> t = UTCDateTime("2014-05-23T22:35:30")
>>> print t
2014-05-23T22:35:30.000000Z
>>> t = UTCDateTime("2599-05-23T22:35:30")
>>> print t
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/obspy/core/utcdatetime.py", line 895, in __str__
    return "%s%sZ" % (self.strftime('%Y-%m-%dT%H:%M:%S'),
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/obspy/core/utcdatetime.py", line 1126, in strftime
    return self._getDateTime().strftime(format)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/obspy/core/utcdatetime.py", line 492, in _getDateTime
    return datetime.datetime.utcfromtimestamp(self.timestamp)
ValueError: timestamp out of range for platform time_t
```

This looks like a bug to me. I found this when working with FDSN StationXML produced by IRIS, where end times (e.g. of a sensor operation period) in the future are often expressed using times very far in the future (commonly end of year 2599), so this is not an esoteric example.

ObsPy version is 0.9.2

milestone.description:
The key new features are support for Python 3, a slew of new file formats, and a new TauP implementation.

[Migration Guide from older ObsPy Versions](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/wiki/What%27s-New-in-ObsPy-0.10.0)

body:
Report on users mailing list:

```
I'm trying to convert sac to wav format, eg
http://docs.obspy.org/packages/obspy.wav.html

My code below creates a wav file of 141KB but it's a flat line.

The input is a seismogram so I don't expect a flat output. Any suggestions?
```

``` python
from obspy.core import read
st = read('http://examples.obspy.org/RJOB_061005_072159.ehz.new')
st.write('myfile.wave', format='WAV', framerate=7000)
```

title: seishub Client.testAuth() not working with anonymous user

milestone.description: Bug fix maintenance release for 1.3.0 (if needed)

body: `obspy.seishub.Client.testAuth()` is always returning `True` regardless if credentials are good/bad, if the user `anonymous` is registered in the seishub server and has read permissions (see https://github.com/barsch/seishub.core/blob/bb4cd198e8c684294a8c5bcccd81f7ca9a2e0963/seishub/core/services/web.py#L163). Also, during `Client.__init__()` we should check user/password and raise if it's wrong.

title: Faulty library file names when installing from source on Python 3

milestone.description:
The key new features are support for Python 3, a slew of new file formats, and a new TauP implementation.

[Migration Guide from older ObsPy Versions](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/wiki/What%27s-New-in-ObsPy-0.10.0)

body:
Installing ObsPy from source on Python 3 produces different library names than ObsPy expects.

The files produced are:

``` sh
$ ls -1 obspy/lib/l*
obspy/lib/libevresp_Linux_64bit_py33_cpython_33m.cpython-33m.so
obspy/lib/libgse2_Linux_64bit_py33_cpython_33m.cpython-33m.so
obspy/lib/libmseed_Linux_64bit_py33_cpython_33m.cpython-33m.so
obspy/lib/libsegy_Linux_64bit_py33_cpython_33m.cpython-33m.so
obspy/lib/libsignal_Linux_64bit_py33_cpython_33m.cpython-33m.so
obspy/lib/libtau_Linux_64bit_py33_cpython_33m.cpython-33m.so
```

Note the `_cpython_33m.cpython-33m.so`.

A file name returned by `obspy.core.util.misc._get_lib_name` is e.g. `libmseed_Linux_64bit_py33_cpython_33m.so`

Unfortunately I do not yet understand the build process enough to debug this further.

I set the Python 3 environment up using @megies' [script](https://github.com/obspy/sandbox/blob/master/buildbots/install_python3.sh).

---

For completeness, this is the traceback produced:

``` pytb
$ python3 -c "import obspy.mseed"
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "./obspy/__init__.py", line 43, in <module>
    read.__doc__ % make_format_plugin_table("waveform", "read", numspaces=4)
  File "./obspy/core/util/base.py", line 394, in make_format_plugin_table
    "obspy.plugin.%s.%s" % (group, name), method)
  File "/home/vagrant/python3/lib/python3.3/site-packages/setuptools-3.4.3-py3.3.egg/pkg_resources.py", line 351, in load_entry_point
  File "/home/vagrant/python3/lib/python3.3/site-packages/setuptools-3.4.3-py3.3.egg/pkg_resources.py", line 2363, in load_entry_point
  File "/home/vagrant/python3/lib/python3.3/site-packages/setuptools-3.4.3-py3.3.egg/pkg_resources.py", line 2088, in load
  File "./obspy/mseed/core.py", line 15, in <module>
    from obspy.mseed.headers import clibmseed, ENCODINGS, HPTMODULUS, \
  File "./obspy/mseed/headers.py", line 39, in <module>
    raise ImportError(msg)
ImportError: Could not load shared library for obspy.mseed.

 ./obspy/mseed/../lib/libmseed.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```

title: Fixed obspy.seedlink bugs caused by mixed usage of class/instance attributes

milestone.description: ObsPy 0.9.2 is a maintenance release and contains the collective bug fixes and minor feature improvements of around 150 commits so we advise all users to upgrade.

body:
This pull request fixes the mixed usage of class and instance variables in some of the objects in `obspy.seedlink`.

The original implementation can lead to unexcpected behaviour, e.g.:

``` pycon
>>> station1 = SLNetStation('', '', None, -1, None)
>>> station2 = SLNetStation('', '', None, -1, None)
>>> station1.appendSelectors('FOO')
1
>>> station2.getSelectors()
['FOO']
```

---

**Edit:** This pull request also fixes ~~#516~~ #561.

http://lists.swapbytes.de/archives/obspy-users/2014-January/001188.html

title: Evalresp fix (see #686) rebased onto releases

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

body: This is #686 rebased onto releases to make it possible to use this bugfix with the 0.8.4 codebase.

title: Evalresp fix

labels.name: .core
labels.description: issues affecting our functionality at the very core

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

body:
`Trace.simulate(seedresp={...})` and `obspy.signal.invsim.seisSim(seedresp={...})` did **NOT** pass the network, station, location and channel codes to evalresp. So if a RESP file contained more than one combination of network, station, location, channel with the correct time span it always chose the first one.

This is a pretty serious bug and we should maybe think about backporting it to the 0.8 release (I did not go through the hassle of the releases branch yet as it would require a lot of manual merging as it is quite deeply integrated...) and sending a mail to the mailing list.

Mostly RESP files are distributed per channel so it worked fine, but when requesting data via the soon-to-be-deprecated IRIS webservices RESP files oftentimes got merged. So it is safe to assume that a fair number of people have unknowingly run into this issue.

I also introduced the mock testing library as discussed in #655.


title: readEvents() returns a catalog with wrong resource_id

labels.name: .core.event
labels.description: issues related to our Catalog/Event functionality

body:
I stumbled upon this while reviewing my `pde.mchedr` module, which has exactly the same problem.

The catalog object returned by `readQuakeML` has not the same `resource_id` than the one created in `_deserialize()` (check by adding a print statement in `_deserialize()`). I think that this is because a copy of the catalog is returned and, therefore, a new `resource_id` is assigned.

title: STA2 header line of GSE2 files
body:
The GSE2 manual defines a (mandatory! see [pdf](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/master/obspy/gse2/docs/provisional_GSE2.1.pdf) page 66, table 6) second header line that we currently do not parse (and also _do not write_!). Besides the _network code_ (albeit possibly SEED-non-conform 9 chars long), it can contain other useful information, namely _station coordinates_:

```
Position  Name       Format                 Description
   1-4   "STA2"   a4        Must be "STA2"
  6-14   Network  a9        Network identifier
 16-34   Lat      f9.5      Latitude (degrees, S is negative)
 36-45   Lon      f10.5     Longitude (degrees, W is negative)
 47-58   Coordsys a12       Reference coordinate system (e.g., WGS-84)
 60-64   Elev     f5.3      Elevation (km)
 66-70   Edepth   f5.3      Emplacement depth (km)
```

In principle we should definitively parse that information.. the problem is that I have seen data from two different sources and both do not adhere to the exact positioning as given in the manual, see e.g. [one of our test files](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/blob/master/obspy/gse2/tests/data/loc_RNON20040609200559.z):

```
STA2           -999.0000 -999.00000              -.999 -.999
```

For example the longitude field goes from 26-35.
A header from another file I saw looks like this (numbers changed):

```
STA2 ABCD       12.34567    1.23456 WGS-84       -123.456 1.234
```

So, to sum it up, currently we are potentially missing useful header information when reading from GSE2. But on the other hand, the data out there seems to not adhere to the official manual. So I am not sure what to do about it.

title: Bug in back-azimuth computation in array_processing

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

body:
In module obspy.signal.array_analysis.array_processing:

When back-azimuth is computed from azimuth, 180 degrees are either subtracted or added. But if azimuth is zero, np.sign() returns zero, meaning instead of 180 degrees, a wrong back-azimuth of zero degrees is obtained.

```
    azimut = 180 * math.atan2(slow_x, slow_y) / math.pi
    baz = azimut - np.sign(azimut) * 180
```

title: RESP file multiple time periods

labels.name: .signal
labels.description: issues related to our signal processing functionalities

body:
Bugreport via devs mailinglist

Hello

the response file reading routine only seems to recognise the first time period defined in the RESP file (rdseed output).  In the attached RESP file there is a change of response on Julian day 273,2012, and the second part of the file describes the response from 274 onwards.  This file works fine with data from before the Julian day 273 but fails for later data (within the time period defined). In this particular example, both responses are in fact equal, so that there is an easy workaround (just modifying the dates in RESP file) but in general there can be a change of response due to a change in sensor or data logger, so it would be nice to get a fix eventually.

Expected behaviour: pick out the right part of the RESP file according to time-period of data to be processed to define response

Here is an attempted minimal example:

``` python
filename='ZE.MS05..HHZ.D.2012.274'
st=read(filename)
respfile='RESP.ZE.MS05..HHZ'
seedresp = {'filename': respfile,  # RESP filename
                    'date': st.traces[0].stats.starttime,
                     'units': 'VEL'
     }
st.simulate(paz_remove=None,seedresp=seedresp,taper=True,taper_fraction=0.005)
```

(edit: corrected code)

title: obspy.iris bulkdataselect only returns last trace in result

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

body:
Issue reported on users mailing list: http://lists.swapbytes.de/archives/obspy-users/2013-September/000980.html
The following only returns part of the desired data:

``` python
from obspy.iris import Client
from obspy import UTCDateTime

t = UTCDateTime("2011-03-11T05:00:00")
client = Client()
st = client.getWaveform("GE", "EIL", "", "BHZ", t - 5*60*60, t + 24*60*60)
print(st)
```

```
1 Trace(s) in Stream:
GE.EIL..BHZ | 2011-03-11T06:47:07.350000Z - 2011-03-12T05:00:00.000000Z | 20.0 Hz, 1599454 samples
```

`getWaveform()` is delegating to `client.bulkdataselect()` with wildcarded location code. Only the last trace of the result set is returned.
Manually using `dataselect` low level method returns all traces:


title: broken `from obspy... import *` in __init__.py's

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

body:
*-imports were broken in 2e06f265. `__all__` takes a list of strings not objects. See http://docs.python.org/2/tutorial/modules.html#importing-from-a-package.

What is actually the reason for this commit? As I understand, this is only necessary if you want objects in *-imports that start with one (or more) underscore(s). And to me it seems unlikely we want an underscore object in a *-import (as the Python guys obviously were also thinking.. ;)  or did you have a specific case for this?).

On the other hand that means additional maintenance effort (two things to add in `__init__.py`s in the future) and thus is much more error prone.

I would vote for reverting at least the redundant cases, i.e. where all previously imported objects are provided through `__all__` and none of those starts with an underscore.

I also would not put `_getVersionString` in `__all__` as the version number should be accessed through `__version__` like in most Python packages I know IMO.

title: Deadlock when using obspy.mseed with multiprocessing

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

body:
I just discovered a nasty issue with deadlocking when reading/writing MiniSEED files in parallel with multiprocessing. It only occurs for MiniSEED files so it is save to say that the error is within obspy.mseed and potentially libmseed.

The following snippet illustrates the problem

``` python
import obspy
import multiprocessing
import time

FILENAME = "./BW.KW1..EHZ.D.2011.038"
FORMAT = "MSEED"


def do_stuff_with_file(filename, process_name):
    st = obspy.read(filename)
    # Sleep to imitate doing actual work.
    time.sleep(0.3)
    st.write("%s.mseed" % str(process_name), format=FORMAT)


class Consumer(multiprocessing.Process):
    def __init__(self, task_queue, result_queue):
        multiprocessing.Process.__init__(self)
        self.task_queue = task_queue
        self.result_queue = result_queue

    def run(self):
        proc_name = self.name
        while True:
            next_task = self.task_queue.get()
            if next_task is None:
                # Poison pill means shutdown
                print '%s: Exiting' % proc_name
                self.task_queue.task_done()
                break
            print '%s: %s' % (proc_name, next_task)
            answer = do_stuff_with_file(FILENAME, proc_name)
            self.task_queue.task_done()
            self.result_queue.put(answer)
        return


if __name__ == '__main__':
    # Establish communication queues
    tasks = multiprocessing.JoinableQueue()
    results = multiprocessing.Queue()

    # Start consumers
    num_consumers = multiprocessing.cpu_count() * 3
    print 'Creating %d consumers' % num_consumers
    consumers = [Consumer(tasks, results) for i in xrange(num_consumers)]
    for w in consumers:
        w.start()

    # Enqueue jobs
    num_jobs = 1000
    for i in xrange(num_jobs):
        tasks.put(i)

    # Add a poison pill for each consumer
    for i in xrange(num_consumers):
        tasks.put(None)

    # Wait for all of the tasks to finish
    tasks.join()
```

Choose a reasonably big file so that the error reliably occurs. After a while, not all processes will keep running. Most will be locked somewhere.

A workaround is to add a mutex around the read and write parts:

``` python
lock = multiprocessing.Lock()

def do_stuff_with_file(filename, process_name):
    lock.acquire()
    st = obspy.read(filename)
    lock.release()
    # Sleep to imitate doing actual work.
    time.sleep(0.3)
    lock.acquire()
    st.write("%s.mseed" % str(process_name), format=FORMAT)
    lock.release()
```

It is worth noting that the same mutex must be used for the reading and writing parts, otherwise it still fails on occasion.

Serializing I/O is not necessarily a bad idea (and might even improve performance). Nonetheless this is a serious issue that we should look into.

title: Version information broken

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

body:
After a few hours of bug tracking (why version information in travis was not working anymore), I found that merging #431 completely broke our version information routine. It happened in this commit (64c54ff) which inadequately replaced the MANIFEST.in with a function in setup.py that adds directories to the installation of the package. The problem is that RELEASE-VERSION generated during installation does not get included. Actually the very general wildcard recursive include (that was introduced at some point 225c46f2 because of similar problems with missing files -- it is just not feasible / too error prone to assume that everybody remembers adding new files in the MANIFEST as well) was replaced by an (older MANIFEST file version?!) include of only some directories, which is missing vital files.

 I understand this was necessary because numpy.distutils does not use the MANIFEST file. However it feels much less clean to have this list of includes hidden in the depths of the setup.py. In any case RELEASE-VERSION has to be included and I am pretty sure that other files might get missed through this, too. This needs thorough checking.

title: check ResourceIdentifier/public_id handling in event/QuakeML output

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

labels.name: .core.event
labels.description: issues related to our Catalog/Event functionality

body:
`resource_id` attributes that are of type `ResourceIdentifier` get automatically adjusted during output to the QuakeML xml string to ensure they are conform with the QuakeML standard (e.g. autoconvert "someid" to "smi:local/someid"). This is nice in principle but unsafe and potentially hazardous, I think.

I stumbled upon it while having a problem with `MomentTensor.derived_origin_id`. The corresponding Origin's public_id got fixed on-the-fly during output but the reference in the moment tensor did not get fixed so the link was broken there and an invalid QuakeML produced.

I will fix this by running getQuakeMLURI() on all ResourceIdentifier objects during conversion to string. However, I think we should consider moving this QuakeML compatibility workaround **right at initialization time, i.e. always make a ResourceIdentifier QuakeML compatible right when it is created** to avoid possible linking problems.

title: malloc error in writeMSEED (Python 2.7.4)

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

body:
On MacOS X 10.8.3, python 2.7.4

``` python
from obspy import read
from obspy.mseed.core import writeMSEED

st = read()

writeMSEED(st, 'test.mseed')
```

produces:

```
Python(21705) malloc: *** error for object 0x7f9e89c74600: pointer being freed was not allocated
*** set a breakpoint in malloc_error_break to debug
Abort trap: 6
```

I trimmed down the problem to  `MSTG.__init__()`.
The same error can be reproduced (at least on my machine) with:

``` python
from obspy import read
from obspy.mseed.core import MSTG

st = read()

tr = st[0]
MSTG(tr, tr.data, 'x')
```

More precisely, it seems to be related to this line in `MSTG.__init__()`:

``` python
chain.contents.datasamples = C.cast(C.pointer(tempdatpoint),
                                            C.c_void_p)
```

Apparently, the problem is the left side of this expression. Doing something like:

``` python
chain.contents.datasamples = 1
```

triggers the same error.

Doing:

``` python
foo = C.cast(C.pointer(tempdatpoint), C.c_void_p)
```

works (but of course generates problems later, since `chain.contents.datasamples` remains `None`)

Clearly, something like:

``` python
foo = C.cast(C.pointer(tempdatpoint), C.c_void_p)
chain.contents.datasamples = foo
```

triggers the same malloc error.

title: obspy.core.read() no return from function when GSE2 chksum is wrong
body:
While trying to read old GSE2 files from the archive, I have experienced problems. I have created a minimal example:

``` python
import obspy.core

def example():
    try:
        obspy.core.read("/tmp/example2.GSE2")
    except obspy.gse2.libgse2.ChksumError as e:
        print "Exception caught: ", e
    print "test"

example()
print "not reached"
```

The input file example2.GSE2 can be found at http://www.seismo.ethz.ch/static/roman/example2.GSE2

Executing this example script will raise an obspy.gse2.libgse2.ChksumError which is caught. After this, anything can be done within the function, as an example I used the print "test" statement. However, the function never returns, i.e. print "not reached" will not be reached.

The example input file truly has a corrupted header. However, I believe the program should throw an exception in this case and return normally if the exception is dealt with.

title: temporary files in obspy.arclink are not removed if download failed
body:
whenever a download request by e.g. client.getWaveform in obspy.arclink fails, the temporary file created in /var/tmp or /tmp or whatever temporary folder is defined by environment variable TMPDIR, remains allocated on the disk, though with size 0.

we ran now into an issue that millions of those dead files had accumulated on our disk. The quick fix on our side was to remove those files manually but I'd like to ask whether this could be fixed at the source?

Thanks,
Christian

title: tr.detrend not respecting masked arrays
body:
Using tr.detrend with masked Traces gives wrong results (due to underlying routines not respecting masked arrays), e.g.:

``` python
import numpy as np
from obspy import Trace
x = np.arange(10)
x = np.ma.masked_greater(x, 3)
tr = Trace(x)
print tr.data
tr.detrend("demean")
print tr.data
```

results in

```
masked_array(data = [0 1 2 3 -- -- -- -- -- --],
             mask = [False False False False  True  True  True  True  True  True],
       fill_value = 999999)
array([-4.5, -3.5, -2.5, -1.5, -0.5,  0.5,  1.5,  2.5,  3.5,  4.5])
```

title: Wrong version number of installed from version controlled directory
body:
I just discovered an interesting edge-case issue that cost me the better part of an hour.

When installing ObsPy via pypi, the version number is usually discovered via the `RELEASE-VERSION` file.  The number in the release version file is overwritten if one executes within a git repository and replaced by a value derived from `git describe --dirty --abbrev=4 --always`. This is fine, except if one installs via PyPi from within another git repository. Then the `RELEASE-VERSION` file will be replaced by whatever value the aforementioned git command returns in the current repository. `pip` always creates a subdirectory in the directory where the command is executed in and then runs everything in there. I guess `easy_install` is doing it in a similar way. Git then searches all parent directories until a `.git` folder is found and considers all subdirectories as being under version control.

While this is minor I think this can actually happen quite a bit.

title: stream.rotate() produces "cryptic" error message when called without arguments

labels.name: release blocker
labels.description: critical issues blocking the corresponding future release

body:
`stream.rotate()` can be called without arguments. In this case, according to the documentation, the rotation angles will be obtained from `stats.ba` and `stats.inc` from the first used component.

Now, if the used stream does not contain this information, `stream.rotate()` produces an error which may look quite cryptic to users:

``` python
KeyError: 'ba'
```

That's the case, indeed, when one tries with the following example:

``` python
from obspy import read
st = read()
st.rotate()
```

title: arclink.client.getWaveform(getPAZ=True) looping
body:
I ran across an example where getWaveform(getPAZ=True) loops "eternally". In the below example, a 2h data request returns >2400 traces.

Checking arclink/client.py, I see that in getWaveform(getPAZ=True), getMetadata() is requested for each trace in the stream. However, not with the start/endtimes of the trace but of the request. Thus the same request is posted over and over again.

Thus I wonder if it would be sufficient to call getMetadata() only once (per channel) with start/endtimes of the request, or start/end of the earliest/latest trace, respectively? 
At least if len(st) > len(requestedstations)*3 ?

This is surely an extreme example but in my case this leads to a huge delay in a data retrieval routine.

Cheers,
Christian

---

from obspy.core import UTCDateTime
from obspy.arclink import Client
#### station and time info

network = "BS"
station = "JMB"
location = ""
channels = 'BH*'
torigin = UTCDateTime("20120529070000")
duration = 7200

client = Client(debug=True)
st = client.getWaveform(network, station, location, channels, torigin, torigin + duration, getPAZ=True)

title: obspy.taup: statically creating taup tables does not work for different fortran compilers

milestone.description:
The key new features are support for Python 3, a slew of new file formats, and a new TauP implementation.

[Migration Guide from older ObsPy Versions](https://github.com/obspy/obspy/wiki/What%27s-New-in-ObsPy-0.10.0)

body:
Hi, everyone.  I installed obspy.taup into the Enthought Python Distro 32 bit, and don't recall having any problems with the install.  When I call taup, however, I get the following error (below).  I don't have any problems using taup in the EPD 64 bit distribution.  I'm using OS X 10.6.8.  In looking at seteup.py, there seems to be a "-fno-underscoring" flag that should be passed along.  Perhaps this isn't being passed?
I apologize if this has been covered already; it didn't look like the previous issue with gfortran.

Thanks in advance!

Best,
Jon
